												Tower defense at its best. Being able to place your towers in such a way that it forces the baddies to take longer paths is extremely enjoyable and challenging.Key features:- Block baddies just as they're getting near your cores, forcing them to re-route.- Bounce a train of baddies back and forth between two paths by repeatedly opening one and blocking the other.- Unspent money earns interest so if you build just the towers you need, you'll have even more money later on.- Create "kill zones" with your most powerful towers + slowing towers + bonus money towers to maximize efficiency.- Cool story with some great DLC (The Portal cross-over DLC is top notch)- Alternate modes/achievements will keep you playing for a long time

												This is not only an excellent tower defense game, it's just plain fun to play.  The base game has plenty of maps and a great selection of different towers to place.   The game is very challenging to find all the right combo's of towers and also the placement of the towers.  Plenty of different aliens make their way onto the map, learning what aliens are on each map will really affect what towers you will use.  Right clicking on an alien will provide much needed info about the alien to help you make tower choices. The UI for the game is very good, making it easy to get towers placed quickly. The wide variety of maps and types of games you can play on each map keeps the game fresh and keeps you coming back to play once again trying to get all gold medals on every type of game.The story line also makes the game fun as well. I'm still playing the base game right now and nearly have story mode complete and already have 70+ hours logged on the game and am not bored with it one bit and I still have all the DLC to get into as well. I highly recommend this game as a good challenge but something you can sit down and play anytime.

number of helpful: 60 of 61 people (98%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 19, 2015
												As of this writing, this game is almost 7 years old. For perspective, it came out only a year after The Orange Box did. When it was first released, it was undeniably the best tower defense game in the world -- but that's not surprising, because its only competition was Desktop Tower Defense and a handful of other shoddy flash games that were starting to ride the trend.A lot of time has passed since then, and hundreds of weird and interesting tower defense games have been released. So, is Defense Grid still the best? ...Honestly, I have no clue. I haven't played as many tower defense games over the years as I would have liked, and I blame it all on the quality and longevity of this one. The people who made Defense Grid understand where tower defense came from. Everything about this game is built to look, feel, and sound like retro StarCraft, from the isometric view, to the color choices, to the tower types and damage types. Gun towers are basically bunkers of marines, inferno towers are bunkers of firebats, cannon towers are bunkers of ghosts, and so on. They’ve even borrowed some classic towers from other games, like the tesla coils from the Red Alert series. Even today, it still hits me with that old 2002-era nostalgia of searching for tower defense maps on Battle.net and that pumped feeling of starting the map with a full lobby of people (because, of course, you needed a full lobby to even have a chance!)The biggest reason why Defense Grid is so great is because of its scoring system, which rewards even the tiniest improvements in performance with exponentially more money and score. It appeals greatly to the gamer's OCD, since the better you play the beginning of a mission, the more freedom you have to build deadly mazes for the remainder of the mission, the easier victory becomes, and the more often you can see your score skyrocket into the hundreds of millions. Fast-forward and checkpoint-rewinding controls make it simple to re-do every wave until it is perfect. It also creates an ultra-hardcore metagame with a massive curve of leaderboard scores, if you’re into that kind of competition. You’ll need to learn some really annoying advanced techniques if you want to break into the top 100 on any mission, or you could choose to compete in maps and game modes where the techniques don’t apply. Or you could simply choose to compete with yourself and your friends, or just aim for the pre-set gold medals. It’s really up to you.I've got over 130 hours logged into this, and I'm finally coming down the home stretch of getting all the achievements. God, this game has a lot of content, thanks to over 4 years of continued support and expansion sets. The expansion sets are quite solid, too; at one point I thought I had found a strategy which works on any mission, but then the DLC campaigns came and changed all the rules, and made me rethink everything.Is Defense Grid still the best? Probably not, and I will have a lot of tower defense games to explore once I’m done with this one. But one thing is for certain: this game is the sole reason why future tower defense games had to start trying new things, because it got the basics about as perfect as they can possibly get… at least for those of us who still occasionally see hordes of zerglings filing through mazes of bunkers in our waking dreams.

number of helpful: 61 of 66 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												This is by far and away the best tower defense game I've played. The game is very simple to play, pick a tower type, choose where you want to put it, watch it kill aliens. The aliens are trying to steal power cores, your job is to kill the aliens before they can make off with them. You start with limited money, but gain more by killing aliens. The challenge comes from making the best tactical use of that money. You need to pick the optimum type of tower for the available locations to place them in. Some of the maps are cleverly designed to let you place towers  and divert the path the aliens take to the cores. Choose wisely and your towers will kill lots of aliens, earn you more money for more towers, and the power cores will be saved. Choose badly and you will slowly be overrun and the cores lost.    All of the maps have massive replayability with different modes offering different objectives. Your scores are also ranked against everyone else who has played. Think you found the optimum way to play a map? Take a look at the highscores and think again! Scores are based on the number of cores you managed to save, the money you have left at the end of a map and the sale value of the towers that you have built. The less you have spent, the better your score will be. Getting the highest scores requires using the bare minimum of towers leaving you constantly on the edge of failure.  Experiment, improve your tactics, watch your name rise through the ranks. There are literally 100's of hours worth of gameplay to be had from the main game, and 100's more from the DLC, which is all excellent.

												By far the best tower defense i have ever played. Tons of content.The game allows for a ridiculous amount of customization, you have so many towers to choose from, and you will definitely have your favorites. There must be hundreds of ways to effectively crush the enemy.combination of towers + tower placement and which towers you will upgrade first + the resource system (that gains interest depending on how much you have in the bank) gives you so many options for strategy.each map, and there are a lot, will have different challenges and modes - that allow for huge replay potential. different layouts and enemy pathing has you thinking tactically about how to maze the aliens into oblivion. easy checkpoint system that lets you go back in time in set intervals, meaning a small error will not force you to restart from wave 1 if you are going for that perfect run.Practice mode give you a ton of cash to perfect a strategy you want to apply once you play the map for real. Great voice acting for a tower defense. its just an amazing game.... I cannot think of a single fault for it. Enemies are varied wth nice animations. Towers look and sound good, upgrades improve their looks and fire effects.... its just obviously handled with a lot of care and love.If you like tower defense - you would be hard pressed to find a better one than Defense Grid. If you do, LET ME KNOW, because i would instantly buy that game too.I highly recommend this game for yourself, or even as a gift to strategy loving friends.This game is AWESOME.

												Simple concept and easy to get into yet a challenge to perfect. Every level has multiple ways to succeed (& fail) which means even when you get your all your Gold medals you still can go back and play it completely differently. This is a rare trait to see in a game to have such good balanced mechanics (between real-time & strategic planning) and level design that it constantly feels fresh! Balance continues in the tower design & difficulty levels where it often feels like a real tug-of-war with the aliens.This and all the DLCs are exceptional fun, worth every $$$ and even going on 5 years since I purchased I still find this game a great experience. It is the definitive Tower Defense game with replayability not often seen in the modern world of disposable gaming. Cannot say a bad thing about the game other than it will consume your soul and spit out Rasberries!! - You'll keep coming back to play again and again. Graphically, it is feeling a little low-def in 2014, but does not detract from the experience.I would definitely say it's worth the standard price. It's a truly big game, packed with everything one could ask for in this genre.

Posted: August 10, 2015
												I certainly enjoyed Defense Grid when it first came out. But what has surprised me is that, over the years, I find myself periodically coming back to pick fights with those stoooopid aliens.  Seldom does a game have such long term interest.With the add-ons and all the variations one can play, there's plenty to enjoy.  The artwork has stood the test of time, and then some!   Sometimes I'll settle into a favorite scenario that I know I can win, but do it with imposed restrictions -- not allowing myself to use certain towers.  Some just to zone out.I have enjoyed DG2, but not nearly as much.  Not sure I can pin down why.  Weird.  Too many voices, perhaps, and poorly delivered dialogue.   Dollar for dollar, Defense Grid is a super value.  If you have ANY interest in tower games, you MUST have this one.  BTW, it's an interesting game to draw children into computer strategy.  Of course, that can be good OR bad.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
												This to me is THE tower defense game, that i compare every other TD to. Now, if that wasn't enough to make you buy this game, here's a bit more in depth analysis:The real challenge in this game comes from the level design. The large open areas don't give you even grids like 10x10 to build your mazes, instead, they give odds like 8x7 etc. So most of the times i found myself thinking that:"Damn, if i put them this way, i could direct them to that area, but then the damage suffers pretty greatly..". Most other TD games just give your enemies a pre-determined path, that you put towers alongside of it, and usually one tactic works in every level.Most TD games i've played give you usually a path of two that the enemies go, in this game, you can create a proper mazes on your own, on most levels. That increases the re-playability a lot, and often i find myself trying some level again just to test out a different strategy.The towers are pretty basic ones, all with 3 levels. There's the gun tower, flamethrower which acts like "poison", heavy hitting cannon, laser, slower, air, concussion that does huge damage to land groups, and command tower that increases the money gained from kills/shows stealthed units better. So nothing too deep in that department.  But nothing more is even needed. In my opinion this game wuold be too much of a hassle with deeper tower system. Since the levels require thinking.The levels itself, there are a good amount of them, and dlc's add a lot more. Every level also has different modes like 99 waves, lesser cores (that enemies steal), core's that stay where they're dropped by an enemy that's killed (these are challenging), restrictions that you must complete the level using only lvl1 towers, and many more different challenges.if you're a fan of TD games, this is one of the must-play game of that genre. Really. I haven't encountered a single bug ever on these 134 hours that i've played this, runs perfectly on win 10.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												Defense Grid takes the tower defense genre to the next level. I liked every aspect of the game. Level design, tower design, tower diversity, enemy types, economic system, soundtrack, effects, difficulty level, extra playable modes, the fact that tower placement shapes the aliens path. Everything is designed very carefully and delivers a perfect playing experience. I got all achievements and I'm still playing to earn the gold metal on every single mode of every level.I admit that the first time I played DG I looked down on it because it looked like a "small" game. That was on a friends computer before I finished the main campaign. Then I played it again a year later on my brothers computer and finished the main campaign again! Finally, this summer, I got it for myself and finished it again, plus every expansion that was available.I'd like also to note that the voice of Jim Ward, who voices the AI assisant, is a big plus for the game. It gives you the feeling you're together into the fight, with a person that shares his personal moments with you, even his craving for raspberries!!The Containment, You monster, Resurgence and Borderlands expansions add greatly to the game, in playable levels but also in the story.And above all else is the Strategy. You may beat easily a level the first time, but it's certain you will come up with a better plan the second time you play the same level. And different game modes (like "out of bullets" or "shredder") will force you to adopt a completely different approach to beat the level. And all of this is done by placing just 10 different types of towers on those tiles. The game depth is incredible.I give this game a 100% with honors! An excellent idea, a perfect design into a superb game.

content:
Posted: April 19, 2015
												Defense Grid: The Awakening made by Hidden Path Entertainment  is one of the better tower defense games you will find on Steam, even now. The game has classic maze building maps and a plethora of towers  at your disposal. You play as a defender of your planet against a volatile alien race that must be destroyed at all costs. To help you accomplish this, you must protect power cores important to your planetary defenses. And what better way to increase your chances of success than an old soldier from the past, that has dealt with them before, whose consciousness is downloaded into a computer to aid you in this undertaking. Alright, maybe the story has a little cheese, but most people play tower defense games for the challenge and difficulty. The graphics of Defense Grid are pretty good considering most tower defense games. I like how the zoom in feature has a lot of detail and eye candy. The sound effects are generic futuristic sci-fi. The game has music soundtracks on the levels to help set the mood and they aren't all bad. (OK so you wouldn't play this game for the music.) This game scores you on a badge system, bronze being the worst. To get a higher score you have to finish the level with a higher resource number, which can be a challenge if you are use to spamming towers. (So, just don't.) There are also different types of modes/challenges per level which will have you reloading plenty of times. (Yes, the backspace key is your friend.) Defense Grid: The Awakening will have you hooked for hours trying to get gold badges and achievement hunting. If you like sci-fi settings and tower defense games this game is a must have. Happy gaming.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												This is easily the oldest Tower Defense on Steam, and is probably a bit of an obvious first choice for talking about them. But it's an obvious one for good reason, as Defense Grid is one of the best of them on Steam even being eight years old at this point. The premise is simple enough: aliens have invaded earth and are spreading chaos and destruction to...do something, they never really get around to saying what. Your player, an unnamed civilian, manages to escape the onslaught and reactivate an ancient defense system, as well as the AI operating it, the mind of the late General Fletcher. He serves as your mission control, and is pleasant enough to listen to even though it doesn't take very long to hear every line he has.Together you set about using the grid to defend against the alien attacks, since the cores powering it are a far more appealing target for them than the Earth's population. Every level aliens will try to make their way to the terminal housing them. That's where things get complicated, as rather than taking health off you immediately, if one makes it there they'll grab up to 3 cores before turning around and trying to make off with them, either out where they came in or on a different path entirely. Kill it and the core will drop and float back toward the housing, but this also means another alien can pick it up themselves. Ideally this means you don't want them making it to the core at all, but in many instances this isn't possible, creating a tug of war.You have quite a few tools to deal with this, of course, as you have all the usual tower types: the fast, low damage Gun tower, the high damage, slow Cannon tower, three different area of effect towers, and more. The campaign is 20 stages long and unlocks them at a good enough pace to keep letting you use new things. Every stage also has a great variety of places you can put them, too, and it's often crucial to alter the alien's path as much as possible, as the aliens have a lot of tricks of their own. Past the first ordinary enemy, there are extra-durable ones, extra-quick ones, ones shielded from most towers, and stealthy ones that won't ordinarily be targeted at long range are just some of the ones they'll throw at you. There are also bosses, and combinations of all of these can be pretty taxing at times. Luckily Defense Grid has what I wish other games in the genre would crib, a checkpoint system. If you mess up in a level you can simply go back a bit in the level and be more prepared, instead of doing the whole thing over again.The game's campaign is easily enough to get your money's worth full price, and especially on a sale, but each level also has a bunch of alternate versions to it with various conditions, like not being able to upgrade your towers. If you want to give those a try you could easily spend a ton of hours watching aliens march to their doom. There are also the Containment and You Monster DLCs, which feature smaller campaigns (the latter of which swaps in Fletcher for none other than Portal's GLaDoS), and four map packs that contain two stages each. So for content, and good content at that, you can't really beat this game. To top it all off, every different level and variant on it has a scoring system to it, allowing a conservative player to compete with others. I haven't played the sequel to the game, but I've heard it's a bit lack-luster in comparison, which is a shame, since Hidden Path pulled it off so well here.

content:
Posted: October 2, 2015
												One of the best "tower defence" games around, with a decent number of maps (26 in the base package, more available as DLC), several challenges and alternative game modes per map, clean graphics and very entertaining voice acting (an American doing an over-the-top "English butler" accent).It's not without its problems, though. For example, the camera can't be rotated or zoomed out very far (which makes the range of some towers almost impossible to judge), the mouse cursor doesn't move freely (it just jumps from button to button), the UI is rather basic and text-based (no easily recognisable icons), and (perhaps more annoyingly) there is no way to see your score before you finish each map (which is just incomprehensible, since some of the challenges involve aiming for specific scores).Also, there are almost no graphical options, no way to enable antialiasing in-game, no manual saves (it auto-saves at predetermined checkpoints, but you lose those checkpoints when you finish a map), and everything seems to have been dumbed down slightly to work on consoles and touchscreens. To give credit to the developers, those limitations aren't nearly as annoying here as in most console / tablet ports, but they still make the game worse than it could (and should) have been.For the price I paid (under 3€), it's definitely worth a buy, and the same would probably hold true for anything under 10€.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
												A nice tower defence game. It doesn't differ too much from other TD games, but it's pretty fun once you get a hang of it. Most of the standard mechanics associated with TD genre are here: a good tower variety, a good enemy variety, rock-paper-scissors tactic of using the right tower against the right enemy, scoreboards, and so on.Graphically the game is very beautiful. Though at times I wished the towers looked a bit more different to one another, otherwise it can get confusing what is what. I do like the whole colour scheme of green towers being basic, yellow advanced, and red the best. The musical side of things could've been a bit better though. Most levels have between 20-30 waves, and can take a while to play through, so it would've been nice to have it spiced up with more memorable tunes. The A.I. narrator most times provides a nice commentary and keeps you entertained with his colourful personality, though at times he can be annoying when he keeps telling you about cores being stolen. *shakes fist*Most levels had a very interesting design and forced you to think hard on how to channel enemies down a longer path and where would be the points of highest offense. They provided a nice challenge. A few felt like difficulty spikes and seemed unnecessarily convoluted (looking at you, Waste Disposal), but most were a great fun.There were a few aspects that annoyed me slightly, so might be worth mentioning them. First one which I noticed straight away was how much punishment the enemies could sustain before going down. Even the weakest, most basic enemies could absorb a fair amount of damage, which in turn made many towers feel too weak. And this brings me to another one. Majority of towers are very situational and tend to have a lot more shortcomings than strengths. The only tower that I felt was all-round good at just about everything was the Cannon tower, and these usually formed the meat and potatoes of my defence, with all the other towers just acting in supporting roles. It's not necessarily a bad thing, but it means there is a bit too little room for experimentation with various setups.Aside from the story mode, each map also has a variety of other modes, most providing some form of a new challenge, like enemies being tougher, or the cores which you must protect not going back to their starting location, and so on. So there's a lot of stuff to try out here and the completionists can easily sink tens or hundreds of hours in this game.Overall, it's a fun TD game. Don't expect anything new and extraordinary, but if you like the genre, then you should definitely grab this game.

content:
Posted: November 12, 2016
												A historic entry into the tower defense genre.In many aspects Defense Grid has aged very well. The level design/variety is superb - Having very different levels is crucial for forcing the player to not get locked into certain strategies. The tower balancing is excellent compared to most entries in the genre - I think cannon towers are a tad overpowered, but not at all game-breakingly so.Defense Grid incorporates my favorite Tower Defense mechanic - unspent resources earn you income (at least in a majority of the game modes). This encourages the player to keep their defenses as lean as possible to maximize the amount of available resources for later waves. With this, even "easy" levels are still very challenging for trying to achieve the highest score.With a ridiculous amount of levels and score-keeping for them, you can compete with your friends' scores. The biggest weakness Defense Grid suffers is that it feels too "vanilla". Not only was its design direction not particularly brave with any novel mechanics to begin with, but due to its age, later titles have been afforded the opportunity to duplicate its successful elements while also putting a more novel spin on their mechanics.Still, what it lacks in novelty, it far surpasses in being an overall sleek optimized tower defense game.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
												I remember playing this years ago on Wild Tangent, long before I switched to Steam, and it's still just as fun as it was then, maybe even more now that I know what to expect.Defense Grid is among the best you'll find in the Tower Defense genre, and rightfully so. This game has a tantalizing blend of simplicity, planning, general enjoyment and even graphics. One of the largest pluses to Defense Grid is that it allows you to progressively shape the path your alien foe take. You can also set up "kill zones," places where you concentrate your best towers and where most of the killing happens, hence the name.Another huge twist in Defense Grid is that your enemies have to go to a central hub to take a power core, essentially hitpoints. If you kill an alien who is holding a core, the core will progressively float back to the hub unless another alien grabs it. This makes strategy much deeper than "don't let them get to the end."Your AI friend who is booted up in the prologue is your constant companion, giving you tips and commenting on how you're doing or what's going on (this has saved my♥♥♥♥♥many times when I was focused on improving outer towers and he told me that aliens had their grabby little hands on a core, and they wouldn't left the map with it if my AI friend hadn't told me in time).Another great, possibly unintentional twist is that your AI friend has a British accent. This somehow makes his warnings more spoken and his cheers more cheerful, plus it sounds so classy when he says "bloody hell."Some maps also have multiple levels to them, where aliens have to go up in a spiral to get to your cores. This opens up a huge amount of possibilities for towers that help cover multiple levels.Overall, I'd have to say Defense Grid is one of the best if not the best game you'll find in the Tower Defense genre. Your Tower Defense collection can't be complete without this game. Definately get this if you're into Tower Defense.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												Gameplay - This is a tower defense game which means you build towers on a map which have their own unique different ways of attacking waves of enemies.  These type of games are all about strategy and experimentation.  You have ten different towers available in each level and have to find the best way to kill all the enemies before they can escape the map.  Unlike the early tower defense games in Warcraft III, Defense Grid has a set number of places where you can build so it becomes important to learn how best to use the space you have and what towers should go where.  You can also shape the paths that enemies take (you always want them to take the longer and more difficult path) which is a cool innovation for the genre.  The designers were smart to put a fast forward button in Defense Grid.  It helps more experienced players get through most maps in 10-15 minutes.  The only downside is much like the Run button in Final Fantasy 7, you have to hold down the F key for long period of times which does get tiring.  It is almost as if a slow down button would have been better than the fast forward.The most important thing is that this game is fun and even addictive at times.  There are over hundred-fifty different modes in the base game alone.  A new player to Tower Defense may find that this game can be challenging without a good strategy so I highly recommend checking out Youtube for any levels that give you trouble as there are lots of good strategies already out there.Story - Like a lot of action-oriented games, Defense Grid tries to have a story when there really isn't room for an interesting one.  It is more like there is an "announcer" for the game who makes comments about certain things and encourages you to beat the game essentially.  The story does not get in the way or waste any of your time which is probably for the best. Presentation (Graphics and Sound) - The graphics in Defense Grid are not very impressive but that isn't the reason you play a game like this either.  The textures are not very detailed and look aged, but this has a nearly top-down and zoomed out camera so it is hard to make the graphics look that great anyway.  The effects of the towers do look good and the game never lags no matter how much action is going on.  This is a plus because old tower defense games could not handle huge waves of enemies.  The sound is good with nice explosion sounds and the announcer is charming and never gets annoying.  What little music is in the game is very good.  If you play through everything in Defense Grid, the music will eventually get repetitive and you'll probably want to listen to something else instead but that is true of any game you play for a long time.Overall Score - Defense Grid is a great game if you enjoy Tower Defense.  It is probably daunting to a beginner, but if you know you like these kind of games, this is easily the best 2D one on Steam at the time of this revew.  This game is now cheap and if you catch it on sale, it is an incredible value.  There are three DLC packs and all three of them are pretty good and add new level designs to the game.  One is tied into Portal so if you like Glados,  you will definitely like that.  While it took me just over 100 hours, this game is pretty easy to get all the achievements.  A few achievements are a grind, but every achievement is pretty easy to get and there are plenty of videos on Youtube to help you figure out how to get them.  I never expected to play this game so much, but the fact that it is fun kept me playing for over 100 hours.8.0 (out of 10)

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												Rating 8/10Overview: Tower DefenseThe Good+ The premise is a bit different than most tower defense games. Rather than the enemies reaching the end of the map, this game has the enemies collecting 'cores' from a specific point on the map and then moving towards the exit. Because of this , your strategy has to be a bit different when placing your towers. In addition the more resources you collect the more interest you earn, thus spending your resources to build/upgrade your towers may not always be the best strategy especially in the beginning of a level. +20 Main missions and 28 DLC missions. Every map is completely different from the last, some maps have multiple entry and exit points, core locations, pathways. Every map almost feels like a new puzzle, trying to figure out how to make the optimal path to win. + The DLC missions are unique and fun. The best DLC levels is mixing the portal universe with this one. Each level is unique and provides an interesting twist to each level altering your strategy.  + Every mission features a variety of different modes. The modes that cause you to rethink your strategy are probably the best ones. For example, one mode has the entry and exit points reversed, another you can only build level 1 towers, etc. + The game features a variety of different towers each one with a unique purpose. The type of tower and the placement plays a big role in the game. + Great graphics and effects for this type of game+controller supportThe Bad:- Other than a variety of different modes per level, this game offers little new. -Some modes can be very repetitive. Once you figure out what works in a level, you can play different modes with the exact same layout. However these modes are optional. - The game feels like it was designed with the controller only in mind. Why can't I map every control function on the mouse?

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												So, Defense Grid. Is it worth your time and money?The short version: yes it is.The long version: keep reading.To start of with the best part, Defense Grid is a TD that focusses on plotting your layout. There are no close to a hundred different tower types here nor are the levels a micro frenzy of having to click at spots at just the right time. Defense Grid is a game about strategy. It's about being so shrewd that your placement of only a handful of towers will obliterate wave after wave.Having only nine towers is a good thing as it focusses attention. You have these nine to master and no more. The learning curve is found in how to combine them.Lasers set aliens on fire, meaning they deal damage even after they left range. But they are useless against shields, which means you need guns or cannons to bring those down. But what if there are speedy aliens in the wave? You need lasers again, or perhaps temporal towers. It's a game about combinations both in placement and upgrades. And speaking of upgrades, there are two upgrades for each tower, each merely increasing the stats of the tower. More damage, more range, faster firing speed. This again, simplifies the learning curve yet the doubling in price for every upgrade still makes it an important choice. You can upgrade two green towers to a yellow one for the price of upgrading one yellow to a red one. Which is better? Well... what's your layout like?The aliens themselves offer variation as well, although it's not so much the power each alien type possesses. It is when these powers are combined within waves that real danger appears. You even might need to take the next wave into account. A wave of very fast aliens, having sped by your defences, stole cores. That's fine, you think. They are all low health, I get them when they re-enter my grinder on the way back. Unfortunately, the next wave arrived already and contains aliens that shield other aliens. And just when you plan your killing blow, the shield envelopes the thieves from the previous wave. Leaving you to hit backspace a couple of times to revert to a previous save. The smoothest quick load I ever encountered in a game.Even the resource gain has a strategic consideration in the form of interest. This mechanic will steadily increase your resources based off a % of what's available. Less spending means more income, requiring you to look ahead. That's the reason why at the top of the screen the next wave is already approaching as a set of clearly identifiable icons.The DLC offers new gamemodes and maps, Ranging from modes where building of the towers is changed, to modes where the behaviour of stolen cores is changed. Each brings only subtle change, but instantly changes the dynamic of any map.The multiplayer aspect of the game is found only in the scores. Everyone on your friend list who owns the game will show up with their scores provided they played that map/gamemode combination, thus inspiring an ever increasing optimization race to eke out just a few more points than them.Of course, afterwards you switch to the global highscores and you will cry silently in your hands as you didn't even realize numbers as big as those existed. The downsides then.The biggest problem is that once you get good at this game several of the gamemodes lose their lustre. Especially the Grinder modes become a bore, having to wait for a hundred waves doing nothing. Not even the ability to speed up the game can make this time go by fast enough.Another problem is that the Tesla tower grows useless. This isn't because it is, but because its intended role as a fail-safe tower, isn't required for a good player. A good player doesn't need fail safes.And finally, there are people who continuously manage to hack/cheat themselves into the top of the highscores somehow, leaving Hidden Path to squat them down again and again. As beating highscores is the endgame for Defense Grid, this is an annoying thing to face.TLDR; There is a demo. Go try it.

												The graphics might look outdated, but make no mistake, this is still one of the best Tower Defense games around. The slightly older graphics give this game a very industrial and gritty feeling, which captures the game's theme very well: Humanity is being invaded by aliens and is on the brink of defeat and your job is it to beat the seemingly endless hordes of aliens by placing several towers at key locations.+ great pacing+ large diversity of towers, each tower feels very unique+ upgrading towers is fun+ watching hundreds of thousands of aliens die in a meatgrinder has never been more satisfying!+ amusing narrator+ ability to speed things up (saves a lot of time)+ myriad content: I've played short of 40 hours, just beating the story missions+ decent variety of aliens+ towers have to be placed in well-thought key locations, creating a well-crafted maze- with about 30 levels in total with all the DLCs maps do get stale- the about 10 alien types get introduced in the very first levels, after that you meet the same types over and over again for many hours

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Amazingly good Tower Defense game. If you like straightforward TDs (no first person, no creating units to attack - just towers and baddies) you will love Defense Grid. Great graphics - they're not CoD of course but this game does more than justice for TD with it's simple design that comes off looking very sleek and setting the mood very well.Fantastic audio - each tower/gun has it's own distinquishable sound. The music is memorable and very well suited.Moreso, the AI companion who keeps you company all game has depth and charisma. He's even got an announcer pack in DotA 2! Tons of replayability - tons of very varied levels to play on, each with multiple different modes to change your challange, and (affordable, and imo very worthwhile) DLC content also add even more content.Amazing gameplay - DG's gameplay is fast paced with a need for good reaction skills and planning, but it manages to also be marvellously straightforward. It's constantly skimming the line of enjoyable challanging and (occasionally) frustratingly difficult, but a well-designed "backtrack" feature in this game takes a big part of what tends to make TD games frustrating. You can always back up a few 10-second blocks of time backwards to re-think just where you place those towers - leaving your gaming time spent playing, killing, planning - instead of re-doing the first few easy waves of a level over and over while you try and handle the challanging part. Whether you're just looking for a fun game to pass a half hour here, or a hardcore lover of Tower Defense, Defense Grid is a damn, damn good game that will get my stamp of approval any day.

												I think it's time to give this game a fair review after over 50-hr playing. Though this game only have the simplest form of tower defense genre: tower, and the only thing you can do is just put them at the proper position, though its art design is just so-so at the present time, but it still give me much fun, excelling many games lying in my library. Its goal is simple. Its learning curve is smooth. It has many different playing mode. Whether you're a hardcore fan of tower defense game or not, you can always find something satisfying you.If you're amateur in this genre, its fighting is intense enough to grab your eyes. When you are a little experienced, its advanced strategy needed to achieve higher goal is easy to understand and learn. And if you have progressed to become a hardcore fan like me, you will catch the art of positioning towers and the timing to position and remove them. Most importantly, you only need a mouse to play. That means you need only one hand, therefore you can play when lying on he bed like a lazybones. Don't need to worry about ache due to unhealthy posture.

Posted: June 30, 2014
												Simply put, this game is awesome, and possibly the best tower defense game I’ve ever played. I love the quick nature of levels, and the thrill of feeling like a pro when you end level with loads of money left over. The range of abilities of the towers makes each level unique. Will you slow a pack of aliens, in a gauntlet? Or maybe zap them over and over with a laser... either way, very fun.At the end of the day, I'd give this game an 8/10. Game play is awesome, and the quick nature makes it easy to pause and get some water. I do wish you could level a tower up more than 3 times. Additionally, I found the menu a teeny bit clunky.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2013
												Sanctum still remains one of the best tower defence games around, so I suppose every other game ends up being compared to it. Well, Defense Grid stands it’s own.  There are a few fundamental differences. The most noticeable is that rather than being down in the action, Defense Grid gives you an aerial view, and it doesn’t have multiplayer either,  but other than that it’s pretty similar to  Sanctum and a great deal of fun to play. There are plenty of levels to keep you interested, and it’s the type of game you can just keep on playing and playing. All in all, highly recommended.  If you want multiplayer, then buy Sanctum. If you want solo play, then buy Defense Grid. Simple really!

content:
Posted: September 7, 2011
												Believe it or not, Defense Grid was the first straight-up "tower defense" game I've ever played (thought I had played other games with elements of TD before). By all accounts, this was a great game to start with, and after many hours of playtime, I have to agree. To summarize the game (as much as I can within the character limit), basically it boils down to this: a bunch of aliens walk down a preset path and it is your job to lay down various towers to stop them from stealing your stuff. The challenge comes in figuring out which tower types to use and managing your resources. The game features tons of levels in the main campaign, along with various alternate challenges for each level. A number of add-on campaigns are also available. There is a TON of content here for a very low price. Considering the addicting and fun gameplay, plus all of the hours of content available, I give this a wholehearted recommendation, even (or especially) for those who have never tried a TD game before.

Posted: December 8, 2012
												I consider this to be the first high production tower game with a quality high enough to hold my interest for dozens of plays.  This is polished as can be, with a deftly delivered narrative to boot.  Plenty of expanstions and challenge modes make it a bargain for the player that enjoys repetition.  The strategies are subtle, the graphics smooth.

Posted: July 17, 2014
												An incredibly challenging tower defense game that focuses more on the placement/location and type of towers you use, as opposed to having an overwhelming number of them like other games in the genre. A strategy that worked for you on one stage may not necessarily work on another, and there is no one tower that is *the best* (sans the slow tower). Most TD games will last you through story mode and not much else, but DG offers plenty of other modes ranging from your standard survival fare to limiting the types of towers you can build, not allowing upgrades, harder enemies, etc. It is hard and ruthless, so if you're not willing to piece out each level like a puzzle you may want to avoid it, but there's no better tower defense game out there.

Posted: January 6, 2014
												This is an economic/financial game as much as a TD game, and I mean that in a good way.  The single biggest factor in your ranking will be how well you underconsumed, saved, and gained in interest.  The game itself is pretty easy, but getting a high ranking is difficult.  The only real flaw with the game, as strange as this may sound, is they introduced too many modes for each map.  As I said, the challenge isn't in completing the level, but in getting a high score, and there's so many maps, with several modes for each one, that there's no way to spend the necessary amount of time with each.  A prime example of how less can be more.  Even still, highly recommended for TD fans.

												Great game that's hugely addictive. I've lost more time to this than is probably healthy but it was totally worth it. Posted: December 22, 2010
												Defense Grid is pretty much the definitive of Tower Defense games. Build a variety of towers, kill alien creepers, earn resources, level your towers, save the day, and still have time to bug your sisters.The difficulty starts out easy enough, but the later levels and the DLC are certainly not for the feint-of-heart. The checkpoint feature is certainly handy though. Did you do amazing through the level until you got to this part and suddenly it all went to pieces? Fear not! With the tap of a single button you can jump back to the last check point in the level and try that again!After you beat the normal campaign, each level offers a variety of other modes that are sure to keep you busy. Some are simple changes, such as simply making it harder. Others add a spin. Such as grinding through 99 waves of creepers, have a single core that kills on contact as it returns to the base, etc.It's no PvZ, but no hardcore TD fan should pass this up without AT LEAST trying the demo.

Posted: November 25, 2013
												This is one of the few games I've enjoyed enough to get every achievement in. The towers are well balanced and are all useful at some point.  Both tall (few upgraded towers) and wide (many low level towers)  builds work on most levels. The levels often have flexible path possibilities. Multiple modes for each level get you to think about the level and tower placement in new ways, and often force you to throw out your old strategy. Compound interest really rewards patience. Checkpoints are great for helping you fine tune a strategy, get perfect placement timing, or back up just a bit when you mess up. Global rankings give you a chalenge to aim for past a gold medal. Easy to play, but harder to master.

Posted: December 27, 2011
												In a genre that's become saturated with "me too" clones, Defense Grid brings a few innovative ideas to the Tower Defense crowd.Unlike most other TD games, the object is not to prevent the baddies from running from point A to point B.  Instead, the baddies are trying to run into the heart of your base, grab a "core", and escape.  You have a limited number of cores, and you can kill any beastie that has stolen one.  The cores gradually float back to where they belong, but they can be intercepted by the invaders.  This adds a tactical layer to the gameplay - you might not want to kill a carrier right away if it means another baddie will grab it and try to escape.The game isn't perfect - it feels a bit sterile and I wish there were better feedback on damage done to the invaders - but easily worth the asking price for anyone looking for a good Tower Defense game.

Posted: May 19, 2011
												A great variation on the tower defense theme. Everyone probably asks whether it is worth buying when there are so many free TDs out there. And I think it is. The game mechanics seem well balanced, gameplay is seamless and there also is an attempt at a story. :) You will proceed through a series of missions in different environments, building towers, upgrading them and repelling wave after wave of enemies. In some levels the enemies take a mostly predetermined path, in others you may shape it, which is yet another important element of your strategy. Over time, you will gain access to an orbital cannon that, if used correctly, can save your hide quite a few times. Automatic checkpoint-based save, quick reloading of checkpoints and a 'fast forward' button provide enough control over the game to avoid boredom and repetition. The biggest con is that even upon completing the game you can't play any mission with all the towers. Only the ones from Story mode of that mission are available.

Posted: June 6, 2013
												An exceedingly addictive and satisfying tower defence game. The graphics aren't totally amazing, but they're not too bad. It's 3D, but it's only really playable in the default viewing mode. There's not much point in zooming in, other than to witness the carnage inflicted by your defence towers when you're feeling particularly confident that you've covered every angle and none of the aliens is going to slip through your net of flames, bullets, incedniaries, lazers and tesla coils. I like the fact that the map is a simplified grid, which makes it easier to adopt a definite strategy. It's why I prefer these sort of tower defence games over other more polished real-time stratrgy games like Starcraft and Command & Conquer. The maps in Defence Grid don't get so big that you have to fret about what's happening off-screen. The optimum strategy may not be entirely evident at the outset and successful strategies tend to emerge as a necessary response to unforseen threats and limited resources. The gameplay has been finely tuned, with statistical targets to hit for achievements and medals. There's also a high-score leader-board, and downloadable content. It's one of the few games that has kept me playing all night.

												If you like Tower defense, this is a great game.  Highly suggest it.  Each map has limited "Build" points, so sometimes you have to get creative in making your own maze within those restrictions. Posted: January 2, 2013
												This game is all right. It's a straight-up tower defense game, but doesn't really bring anything special to the genre. There is unfortunately not a great deal of towers in the game. Once you've seen them in action, you've basically seen the game. I guess this can be seen as a good thing, since it means you must rely on placement and tower knowledge rather than brute force building.I appreciate the amount of work that went into the game. The stages and gameplay are clean and easy to work with. I wish I could see the damage numbers my towers are doing, though. The stat bars don't really tell me anything useful.There's quite a bit of content (with DLCs)! It took me long enough to complete every stage at least once without losing cores. I'm not even going to attempt the additional challenges per stage, though. I've seen enough.To anyone who decides to pick this up, my only advice is to remember that BACKSPACE loads from your last autosave, and you can hit it several times to backtrack further. This is quite useful for attempting perfect playthroughs.Overall I'd rate this a 7/10. Would I recommend it? Ehhhh. I kind of liked some Flash TD games better.

Posted: May 19, 2011
												A great variation on the tower defense theme. Everyone probably asks whether it is worth buying when there are so many free TDs out there. And I think it is. The game mechanics seem well balanced, gameplay is seamless and there also is an attempt at a story. :) You will proceed through a series of missions in different environments, building towers, upgrading them and repelling wave after wave of enemies. In some levels the enemies take a mostly predetermined path, in others you may shape it, which is yet another important element of your strategy. Over time, you will gain access to an orbital cannon that, if used correctly, can save your hide quite a few times. Automatic checkpoint-based save, quick reloading of checkpoints and a 'fast forward' button provide enough control over the game to avoid boredom and repetition. The biggest con is that even upon completing the game you can't play any mission with all the towers. Only the ones from Story mode of that mission are available.

Posted: December 27, 2011
												In a genre that's become saturated with "me too" clones, Defense Grid brings a few innovative ideas to the Tower Defense crowd.Unlike most other TD games, the object is not to prevent the baddies from running from point A to point B.  Instead, the baddies are trying to run into the heart of your base, grab a "core", and escape.  You have a limited number of cores, and you can kill any beastie that has stolen one.  The cores gradually float back to where they belong, but they can be intercepted by the invaders.  This adds a tactical layer to the gameplay - you might not want to kill a carrier right away if it means another baddie will grab it and try to escape.The game isn't perfect - it feels a bit sterile and I wish there were better feedback on damage done to the invaders - but easily worth the asking price for anyone looking for a good Tower Defense game.

Posted: December 27, 2011
												Defense Grid is a good tower defense game, it has a nice story, which is narrated by apparently a british actor. It's all basicly a build up for your defense against aliens. If you've ever played a tower defense game, then you'll know what to expect. There is a nice leaderboard, with constant records that you can beat, medals to earn and such.There is always space for progress and accomplishment. The best tactic to defeat your enemies is to know how and when to place your towers correctly so you can beat your enemy with maximum presicion and prevent any unwanted consequences.If you're looking for a game where you can relax and still have fun with, look no further then Defense Grid.

Posted: June 6, 2013
												An exceedingly addictive and satisfying tower defence game. The graphics aren't totally amazing, but they're not too bad. It's 3D, but it's only really playable in the default viewing mode. There's not much point in zooming in, other than to witness the carnage inflicted by your defence towers when you're feeling particularly confident that you've covered every angle and none of the aliens is going to slip through your net of flames, bullets, incedniaries, lazers and tesla coils. I like the fact that the map is a simplified grid, which makes it easier to adopt a definite strategy. It's why I prefer these sort of tower defence games over other more polished real-time stratrgy games like Starcraft and Command & Conquer. The maps in Defence Grid don't get so big that you have to fret about what's happening off-screen. The optimum strategy may not be entirely evident at the outset and successful strategies tend to emerge as a necessary response to unforseen threats and limited resources. The gameplay has been finely tuned, with statistical targets to hit for achievements and medals. There's also a high-score leader-board, and downloadable content. It's one of the few games that has kept me playing all night.

												Defense Grid: The Awakening is THE definition of tower defense and perfectly combines both nice optics and addicting gameplay mechanics, making it probably the best tower defense game to date.The game features 10 different and upgradeable tower types, 15 different enemy types with various abilities and 26 unique levels in various settings. Posted: December 26, 2013
												Here comes a great tower defense game. Defense Grid will have you assist the awakening of this AI during an alien invasion. While you keep fending off hordes of nasty aliens and work your way through the campaign, your AI buddy will educate you on the different kinds of towers it unlocks for you, and will provide intel on any new kind of alien appearing on the battlefield. In addition it will comment every now and then on whatever is happening on the field, always with its distinctive british accent.Every battlefield can be played in a number of different modes, each providing a different challenge on its own, with different waves of aliens and different perks/limits for you to enjoy different playstyles. Visuals are great. Battlefields encompass railroad stages where aliens will be moving on a fixed path and you'll only be allowed to put your towers on the sides, and stages in which you'll be allowed to alter the alien's path by building a maze of towers. The game won't prevent you from blocking the way to the core, but aliens will only follow the path you draw for them so long as there is a legitimate way to do it: you block the way, they'll ignore the maze and just follow the most direct path. You play fair, they do it too.You can speed up the game a little but there is no pause button, so stay focused. Luckily the game provides a well-designed checkpoint system, allowing you to rewind to any one of the save points for that match should the aliens manage to steal a core or two.Definitely recommended!

Posted: January 10, 2015
												A big big thumbs up for this tower defense game.The campaign is very fleshed out and gives you around 20 levels. After that there are more challenges available.This game wins on so many levels:1.) It is insanely and maddeningly challenging. You will want to replay every mission in the campaign and try not to have any cores taken. 2.) The game rewards you for strategizing and tactics. Incorrectly placed towers will lead you to scream in frustration. Correctly placed towers will give you a huge sense of satisfaction as you correctly and accurately reroute aliens.3.) You can level up each tower with resources gained from fallen aliens. 4.) An insanely high replayability factor. You can replay different missions and see what towers and where works.5.) The voice acting is pretty good, I have to admit. You are kept company on each mission by some British dude talking about his family, his son Zeke, etc. Hammy but a nice touch as you fight off the alien columns.If this is on sale, grab it. One of the better tower defense games. Very, very well done.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												Defense Grid is one of the best tower defense games ever made. It doesn't deviate much outside the norms for the genre - you accumulate funds over time by killing enemies and gaining interest, and then use these funds to purchase and upgrade towers around the path(s) which enemies take while trying to steal your cores. Successive waves are more difficult, and in some levels you actually build the path yourself by blocking their ability to progress with your towers.Later levels are quite challenging, there's a wide variety of towers, and there's also multiple modes which can add different twists to the gameplay. It's extremely well balanced, allowing for multiple play styles to come up with valid combinations which can be effective.Any fan of the genre should own this game, and it also makes for an excellent introduction to what tower defense games can offer.

content:
Posted: January 30
												Picked this up on sale and I've already got almost 10 hours in the game in less than two weeks, and this is the first tower defense game I've ever played or owned.Looks can be deceiving -- this game looks simple, but there's real depth to it, and each successive map opens up new possibilities in terms of strategy and playstyle. The brilliance of the game is how it nudges you out of your comfort zone to try new approaches, without losing what makes it fun.For example, some maps are all about setting up brutal chokepoints that operate like murder mills, with all your firepower concentrated on the alien hordes as they pass through. Other maps require you to set up overlapping fields of fire and cover wide areas because aliens spawn in multiple locations. And some maps are all about closing off alternate paths and forcing the aliens to take the route you want them to take.The towers all have their own strenths. Guns are weak but fire rapidly and can target flying aliens. Cannons pack a punch and can hit flying aliens, but fire slowly. Lasers are great at sapping aliens of hit points, but have a smaller targeting radius and can only harm land units. Inferno towers hit aliens with fire that leaves a DoT effect on them. Tesla towers electrocute aliens. Temporal towers send out pulses that slow aliens down. Missile towers provide air defense. Meteor towers have huge range but fire slowly. Concussion towers shred groups of aliens with AoE explosives. Command towers reveal stealthed enemies and help you recover more resources. And so on...Bottom line: This game is a hell of a lot of fun, and on sale it's practically a steal.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												TLDR: Worth it at almost any price, if you like any sort of TD games.DG:TA is a the perfect execution of a standard tower defense game. As usual, the first few missions unlock new towers as you go, but you have all tower options available for the vast majority of the game (rather than only the last couple levels like many TD games). There's no experience points or carry over from level to level. All towers can be upgraded twice, increasing their range/speed/power. Tower variety is really good.Story (8/10) - For a tower defense game, this is probably the best storyline you'll ever find. It's touching, believable, and satisfying. The voice acting is superb, which really helps with the immersion. While I've not played more than a few hours of Portal, even I can appreciate the ties to the game in a hidden bonus console, as well as an entire DLC devoted to it. The game is worth playing through on the easiest difficulty simply for the storyline.Gameplay (10/10) - Levels are very well balanced. Zoom features are great. There's a "rewind back to a checkpoint" button that autosaves every few waves (and you can rewind back through multiple checkpoints). Different levels force different tactics, so you'll use almost every tower at least a bit. Artillery can miss. Rewinding can alter the rest of the mission simply because it resets where all the bullets are, and some may/may not miss. Fast forward feature works flawlessly. There's both fairly set path levels, as well as completely wide open levels that you can maze up to 'til your heart's content.Replayability (11+/10) - Every level has a whole mess of "challenge" options, such as "out of bullets" (no towers that use bullets), "reverse" (level is reversed), "hard", "no upgrades", "poison" (the objects you're defending kill the enemies if they're dropped), and on and on and on. There's a leaderboard, and multiple medals for each different option on each different map. This is literally hundreds of hours of content. The DLCs are equally as impressive, with a stronger showing of "open concept" levels, they are much harder and present countless different ways to win, and it's rewarding to replay them to find those ways.Sound (7/10) - The effects are good, cannons and explosions are satisfying, ambient noise/music is fitting although you'll probably turn it off if after the first 30 hours (which is pretty darn good anyway). I put the voice acting under the story, but there's fairly consistent comments from your sidekick during the missions that somehow never got annoying even after the millionth time I heard them.Graphics/UI (7/10) - Solidly above average for a TD game of its age. You can zoom in quite close, or zoom out for a view range that's more than far enough. Things look like they're supposed to, enemies are all easily distinguishable. Faster enemies will sometime "outrun" where something hits them, so the bullet hitting animation can be slightly behind an enemy (fairly minor problem). The levels show a really good variety without ruining the believability. Menus are very well laid out, as is the ability to see at a glance how you did on each mission (great if you're trying to get all the medals). Nothing here will blow you away, but nothing will annoy you, which is awesome for a TD game.Achievements/Steam Cards (10/10) - They are there, and work flawlessly!Overall (9/10) - For what it is, it might very well be 10/10. I, personally, enjoy continuity between levels, which is the only thing I would have changed to make it perfect in my eyes. Questions like "Is clicking on specific towers easy, or is mis-clicking common?" are questions that just won't come up in this game. There is nothing that will detract from the fun of this game, nothing clunky, nothing annoying. You will like it, or not, based on the game concept itself, because the execution is simply done right.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 1, 2016
												I recommend this game for tower defense fans, and nobody else. Good balanced game; bit tedious; very bad presentation. In some respects this game is the best tower defense game I've played. I consider it to have flaws which diminish the fun.Tower defense: waves of enemies come, and you build static defense weapons to counter them. Defense Grid is a pretty basic tower defense: despite the appearances, enemies seem to be considered one-dimensional dots on a path; weapons always hit. There's a line-of-sight mechanic though, by which towers can't shoot through other towers, and some towers are higher than others, and the levels are considered in 3D for targeting. It isn't immediately obvious what the barriers for targeting are (some towers are considered lower than their model suggests, many can shoot steeper downward than their models can bend).That is the first weakness of the game: there isn't a direct correlation between what you see and what you get. Even the indicator for how far your towers can shoot seems not to precisely correlate to how far they can actually shoot. So now you can enjoy learning the actual capabilities of your weapons by heart.In some stages Defense Grid let's you build towers in the way of your enemies, so that you can make them take a longer route. Often you need to find the longest route to get a good result on a level; the second longest route won't do. They obviously did a lot of balancing to get the stages to work like that. Also the different weapons are well balanced with their costs. So that's one strong point: very subtly balanced game.Second strong point is the resource management. Keep your "money" in the bank and you get interest. Very simple, but works perfectly for tower defense games. This is one of the points that makes it rewarding to go for a highscore.The towers don't take any orders, tweaks, or diverging upgrade paths. They will however automatically target enemies they're strong against, which is nice on one hand, but isn't very rewarding. A special class of enemies flies and takes a shorter route. Countering them boils down to saving enough money to buy a special AA-gun on time. It all works, but it feels a bit artificially scripted.For some reason you can't zoom out to see the entire stage at once. If an enemy slips by your defense, you will often not notice it immediately. The game has some checkpoints where it autosaves, so you can rewind the game as much as you like to one of those checkpoints. This is a must for getting good highscores.The enemies are shapeless blobs that could have been somebody's first 3D project. The stages look like the part of the background that you can't actually interact with in other games. There's only one BGM (that interactively changes mood). The sounds of enemies dying is either muffled, or sounds like one of your cannons firing. And you have some posh computer companion with a tragic backstory who tells you what to do. Many people seem to be ecstatic about the voice-acting and humor of that character; I found him annoying and overly dramatic.

												Best tower defense game I've played. Very clean UI with a long main campaign and many side things to do after everything is done. MUCH better ones.The upsides are good graphics, lots of maps (if you do like it, you won't run out), and the AI helper is entertaining.  His backstory (what there is) is far more interesting than the story you're playing (kill invaders, the end).I bought it for 2.50 on sale.  For that price, sure, get it.  Don't buy it at full price.

												This must be one of the best tower defense games I've ever played. The graphics are solid, the sounds are decent, but the gameplay is so addictive. There are lots of levels, with lots of different enemies and upgradeable towers. They become increasingly difficult but somehow it never frustrates. And I thank the Fast Forward button for that, a button that allows you to speed things up instead of waiting and waiting for enemies to arrive. It's a good way to see if your towers are set correctly, or if they need to be replaced, moved to somewhere else or even upgraded. Lots and lots of fun to be had here, so make sure you own this game as soon as possible.[Rating: 86/100]

												This is the most fantastic tower defense game ever made! It is simple to operate and very hard to master, to get you in the top ranks. content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
												Gave it another try and the game seems decent, but it makes me not want to play. You have to slowly sell towers at end of a level for higher score and the game doesn't tell you that you gain more interest when you have more resources. It's frustrating not to know this on early missions when you are going for gold medals.I wouldn't have tried the game for longer if I didn't stumble upon this information when googling for "defense grid towers". Not only that, but comparing the game to other TDs that I've tried, it feels a little too slow or too basic.I guess if you like mazing with basic towers (later in the game) or spending time on trying to understand how to beat a level without any knowledge on how to get a higher resource gain, give it a try.

Posted: December 15, 2013
												Standard tower defense game, build towers (limited mazing), kill waves of monsters, defend your main base.  The main difference with this tower defense is that enemies must "steal" lives from you meaning if you can kill them shortly after they reach your main base you can recover those lives they stole.This is a bit older and should probably be ported to mobile as the graphics and gameplay are pretty standard when compared to your average mobile tower defense these days.Nothing new to see here so if you're looking for some sort of complex or rewarding game you'll have to look elsewhere.  If you're just looking for a casual TD with lots of ladders, achievements, and such then you might enjoy it for a few days!

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												I love Strategy games. And it's hard to find good strategy games that I haven't played already and got bored of them. Now, what I love more than strategy games? Tower defense games. And this is the only good Tower Defense game I've seen in Steam so far.The story is okay. I wasn't really expecting something good as Half-Life anyway, but it makes the job. The enemies are generic aliens who want to take over the world, and you, and some sort of IA have to deal with them using towers. Is that simple. Now, what makes the game good? A nice amount of strategy, lots and lots of maps, a good number of towers to use, and LOTS OF MODES to play. And not only that, but there are maps made by comunity members.The DLC's are, most of them, worth it. Good and cheap maps with extra dificulty. If I have to choose one, it's quite obvious the Portal DLC is the best one. And if you're a guy who doesn't want to buy lots of DLC's, just buy this one and ignore the others.I still play this game from time to time. And I had it for like, a year or even more. If that doesn't show that it's good enough, you might want to try it yourself, since it had a lot of sales and price drops during events, like the one going on now.Now, if companies made more of these games, instead of more generic FPS...

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2012
												Here is an example of a really good tower defense game. Story wise, it left something to be desired; it appeared to be just getting interesting when the game concluded. That's not to say it was too short though. The game has a decent length and plenty of additional content added to keep the fun going, but I personally just wanted to know more about what was going on with the classy AI with the obsession with raspberries. The visuals are also great, and allow you to zoom in and take a closer look at the alien action. Overall, everything plays very well, as you would expect from something that can quickly get hairy and hectic. If you're looking for a good tower defense game, curious about them, or even just wanting a reminder of why they're appealing, then look no further than here. This is it.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												There's just nothing to it. It's a pretty simple tower defense game that makes no meaningful improvements over anything you might have played on Kongregate or in WarCraft III custom maps. It's well made, looks pretty nice, and is a top-to-bottom competent product, but given that there are so many kooky variations that not only cost less, but are flat out better, you should give Defensive Grid a miss.

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
												This game SEEMS like a great tower defense game, but I think there's a major flaw: It isn't FUN. The maps are big and there are so many ways you could lay out your defense.... yet, as each defense you try fails or barely succeeds, you get the feeling that there is actually only one or two ways to beat each challenge. That isn't fun to me. I think tower defense games need to choose whether the "solution" to a challenge is intuitive and you can find it after a few tries, OR whether you can decide how to build your defense and there are many ways to win. When a tower defense game gives you many options AND requires you to play a very specific way, I call that TEDIUM. You have to play the whole challenge (they are quite long) over and over until you find out the successful layout.You could say I'm just not that great at the game, but I never consider "you're just not good enough" or "there are people out there who can do it" to be a strong defense (no pun intended) for a tedius and difficult game. I think if I play video games pretty often and I tend to be good at them, I should be able to achieve moderate success in a game without investing hundreds of hours. For that reason, I can't recommend this game. Non-hardcore tower defense fans will probably enjoy this game up to a point then realize that it's is either hopeless or way too time consuming and demanding.

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
												Everywhere I went on the Internet, I was told this was the ultimate tower defense game, excellent in every single detail.Don't get me wrong. This game has an amazing level of polish. It has everything good tower defense games should have. If you have not played many tower defense games, then it is probably going to be an amazing experience for you.However, Grid is exactly that, and no more: a game that takes all the basics from tower defense games and make them work perfectly. There is nothing more. There is nothing new. You will play with the same basic boring towers you have been playing with since the very first TDs on Warcraft. No ambition, nothing new, nothing exciting. Even the strategic depth is minimal, leaving you sometimes with no choice on where to build your towers. It is a great production, but with no innovation. Frankly, some indie games or even some flash TDs are more innovative and addictive.Grid, because it has NOTHING that makes it different from other super-classic TDs, will fail exactly where all the classic ones failed: it becomes quickly repetitive, boring and brainless. Such a shame when we think that a tiny bit of innovation would have made it a seriously great game.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2016
Towerdefense CodeifiedTower Defense. That's all you need to know. Think of your standard Tower Defense Game, Give it some sweet 3d graphics, a challenging difficulty curve and a soothing british voice as a narrator, and you'll have this game. It doesn't do much beyond one new thing compared to the standard tower defense (TD). NO fancy gimmicks, no trick twists, no surprises. IT is as standard as you can get in terms of mechanics. In terms of graphics, this is where the polish comes in and boy did they polish it. What id does add is a surprising bit of subtle story-telling through your AI Advisor. I won't spoil it but really, it's right up there with the Stanley Parable and the Bastion Narrator. Without this guy, the game becomes a well polished but soulless husk of a game.As for negatives. Well  it has a crazy difficulty curve and is not advised if you OCD.. COmpleting the missions is not terribly difficult. COmpleting a mission with a gold star ranking on the other hand... Yeah. Plus each map has a plethora of challenge modes. Really it is the fun sort of game if you like a Tower Defense game that makes you think and plan.About the only othe negative is that there's not really anything here for people who aren't already fans of the genre. If you know you like Tower Defense, give this game a shot. if you're not sure, give it a shot but be careful. YOu'll find the 2 hour limit goes by pretty quickly.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
												Nice challenging fast paced tower defense game that is really great in levels you have great amount of free spots and you can freely build different types of towers and change aliens paths.It gets frustrating really fast in levels where is only few spots and lots of crossroads, you have usually only one way how to beat such levels. You have to quess right order and right time in which you build (or upgrade) right tower, so there comes attemp-fail scheme and frustration of course.Was suprised by controls but got used to it fast. Flying aliens have different paths (different from ground units) its great idea, cause you have limeted number of spots for towers and you have to think more wisely. Also towers are obstacles for each other, so one tower cant fire through the other etc. some game mechanics are great.Real minus for me is that  you cant zoom out or pause the game (well, you can honestly, but you will see only menu then) - there is also no minimap or something, so you cant stop and think about your strategy/next few moves. This game really wasnt meant to be played on small screens/resolutions and slow.I can imagine that with proper hardware the impression can be different, cause presentation is great (graphic, voiceacting, additional content... ) but ... im not sure. This is definitely not game for me (and my PC).
