number of helpful: 1 of 6 people (17%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												You are mankind's last, best hope against the alien horde.   Unfortunately, you are also an intergalactic hobo forced to scrape together every last penny you own to purchase the towers you so desperately need to hold back the alien menace.  Once you own some towers, you can improve them.  Well, you would be able to improve them except that you are far too poor to afford it.  And then at the end of each board, if you manage to hold back the aliens, any money you did manage to accumulate over the course of the board is taken away so you can be returned to a state of abject poverty in preparation for the next board.  Your performance is graded partially on how successful you were in defending the 'cores' (your main objective) and partially on how 'wasteful' you were with your meager funds.  Apparently you are supposed to defend the cores with an absolute bare minimum and if you do manage to build a secure defense that stops the aliens dead in their tracks... well... you've done something wrong and need to be penalized in terms of score.  The layouts of many of the boards are interesting and provide you with many options on how you can halt the oncoming horde... if you had the money to actually carry it out.  I also had the feeling in many places that although it appeared that I had many options, there was a particular way most boards were 'supposed' to be done.  This gives the game the unpleasant feeling of a guessing game where you set up a defense only to find out that the designers had something else in mind, and as the aliens burst through your defensive line you are (as usual) flat broke and unable to change your strategy without backstepping to an earlier point and simply making a different guess.That said, the base concept still makes for an interesting tower defense style game.   The graphics are good and the voice acting is very good.  The towers types are interesting and the ability to actually shape the path of the aliens by blocking some access points with towers gives this game an edge over other tower defense games.  However, I feel that Defense Grid 2 carried these concepts out in a better and more entertaining way than this game.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2015
												Defense Grid: The Awakening is a Tower Defense game where you do what you do in every TD, place towers and kill aliens. It has a solid base and levels achievements are earned by not spending too many resources and keeping all your power cores from being stolen. Everythign works as expected, however I cannot recommend this game.The Awakening is just too basic to get through as a good TD that costs money. I can find many more entertaining games back from the era where everyone was hanging out on Xgen-Studios. There are no upgraded between levels, only the most basic tower models and a nonexistent story. The only thing that this game has more of than most TDs is grapics. There is no motivation to re-play a campaign than any stupid handicaps you can put on yourself, every session is closed in itself and you do not take any bonuses to the next level. Enemies are very boring (5 types of walkers with scaling health, fast ones, flying ones), they only offer the most basic enemies. The game got boring very quickly and I had much more fun playing other TDs for free.

number of helpful: 2 of 10 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16
Product received for free
												(I accidently pressed the recieved for free button, just ignore that, my bad)TLDR version-----------------Pros:- Some fun maps- Good variety of game modes for maps- Good music, sound effects and voice acting- A story that actually works for a tower defense gameCons:- DLC- Too much trial and error- Feels like a puzzle game- Most of the towers are useless- Awkward to play without a controller- Some game modes feel too impossible to beatIn depth review:I love strategy games, in the 90s there was an excess of these games and most of them were good or at the very least worth playing. Most people claim that Warcraft invented the tower defense game genre, but that is far from the truth. These kind of games already existed and Warcraft merely popularized it.That being said, a tower defense game is a different take on the RTS genre. Taking in strategy and a finite amount of space that a player can actually use. I like tower defense games, however I have only played very few games that are ACTUAL tower defense games.Most of games in this genre are nothing more than… how do I put it…. Glorified puzzle games. As in that only a preset combination of towers placed on specific spots will result in victory. Or that there isn’t even a fixed path leaving it to the player to figure out how to shape the way.Don’t get me wrong, I don’t mind these things, but I do mind it when 80% of a tower defense game is like that. At that point it just stops being a tower defense game, because suddenly you’re not using strategy anymore but trial and error in order to win a level.At first I liked the game, in fact I liked the campaign so much I even bought a few DLC packs. Which was a big mistake on my part, I don’t even know what exactly you’re supposed to do. None of the extra maps have a predefined path, none of them. It’s not nothing more than just replaying it again and again until you finally find out where you have to put the towers.Another problem that I noticed is the fact that you have so many towers, yet you could finish most of the maps with nothing more than fully upgraded gun towers. Why even bother using the others? Why even bother playing this puzzle game?So in the end, don’t spend your money on this, don’t even bother with the sequel.

number of helpful: 4 of 18 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
												Story: Simple, yet engagingGraphics: ExquisiteVoice Acting: SUPERBGameplay: borrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrring!Replay value: Please, no... 


YouTube™ Video: Super troopers - Please No 

			Views: 32,966		

			PLEASE NO!		

As tower defense goes, this game generally follows the standard layout/structure (bullets/fire/slow/mortar/missiles). They throw in some interesting ideas of what towers can do (sniper/tesla/command). Unfortunately there are entire levels where you never want nor need most of them - a real waste of options and menu space.Sadly, the gameplay grinds along at what can only be described as "inexorable". Pacing was not a high point of this game's design, evidently. Waves of enemies came and went, but all I really wanted the entire game was a speed toggle instead of having to hold down a key to accelerate gamespeed. I really only looked forward to getting it over with, by the time each level was finished. Level design was interesting but quickly became too big and too bulky. Getting to the end of ten minutes of planning out and building a massive gauntlet, just to find that a single unit can still make it through, was met with dread instead of a curiosity or anticipation. There is little room for error in most of the levels - if you want a good score, that is. Placing a tower that blocked unit pathing was allowed and suddenly they could just walk through your towers with no ill effect. Lastly, fine-tuning the towers (with upgrades) was never needed or necessary - new towers are just better and there is always room for more towers.The final flaw was that each level was far too isolated, lending to a disruptive lack of cohesion in the story. Lost a core (life/hitpoint)? It'll be back in the next level! Lots of resources at the end of one level? Too bad, they're gone! There was great opportunity to build a bank&store system with persistence in campaign, but they obviously missed those chances.The game has some intriguing ideas and some fun DLC (GLADoS content is always good!), but they introduce an obnoxious relay/replace gameplay mechanic that only serves to frustrate and annoy. In summary, the game under-delivers on the core elements of tower defense and underwhelms with its thinly-veiled attempts at innovating on this genre. I cannot give this game a recommendation rating, but it's worth throwing a couple of bucks at it (Steam sales! Woo!) just for the story mode and a single playthrough.

Posted: June 9, 2014
												The game is a twist on classic tower defense games. You'll get hours of fun out of Defense Grid. The gameplay modes help add to the its replayablity. It also has a global scoreboard tracker so that you can compete against the community. A few of the levels have a resource cap mode that starts you out with max resources so that you can perfect your tactics and strategies for the waves of enemies. If you're like me you'll end up with a handful of favorite levels that you keep returing to. I've got plenty of hours into the game so far and I'll have plenty more into it before Defense Grid 2 comes out.

Posted: July 3, 2011
												If you like Tower Defense style games, then this is an easy pick for you.  It has both mazing-style maps and straight-shot creep runs, and a little story line to go with it.  Throughout the story you're being assisted (or assisting)  your "defense matrix".  This witty little robotic entity keeps you company and helps you out with learning each of the new map elements and towers that are thrown at you.  With the storyline, differing maps, and pretty decent graphics, I would heartily recommend this game to anyone interested in Tower Defenses.

Posted: August 6, 2011
												This is a superior Tower Defence game that rewards tactics and preparation. Starting with a gentle learning curve (and one of the few flaws of the game is that the earlier levels act as tutorials which hampers their replay value) it introduces you to an array of towers and tactics, each with their own advatanges and disadvantages against the diverse array of aliens that you would place them to kill.The gameplay mechanics, as befits the genre, are simple: you place towers alongside or in the way of the enemie's path to prevent them passing. Simple to grasp but, with an array of both towers at your disposal and enemies conspiring against you, tricky to master. Many times you find yourself going to earlier save points within a level or restarting it to try a different combination or placement.The sounds are good and the graphics all of a piece and attractive enough. The in game commentary and voice over can get a little annoying sometimes, but does add personality to the proceedings.

Posted: January 1, 2014
												If you're looking for a pure TD game, this is it.  This is the one TD game that I keep coming back to over and over again.  It has a decent enough story to warrant a playthrough, but the sheer number of challenge scenarios on each stage add in lots of replayability.  What you won't find are the gimmicks in some other TD games such as a first-person perspective or being able to control a "hero" to to make the game more "action-y".  This one is strictly placing towers and trying to come up with a strategy to survive, so it's a lot more focused on the strategy aspect of TD games than the action aspect.  There are a lot of Tower Defense games out there, but for a strictly no-gimmicks tower defense game, this one does it best.

Posted: July 12, 2012
												Kicking where it’s due: The game gets repetitive quickly and all the add-ons are more of the same except the portal themed pack (the portal themed pack is called “You Monster”) which like the main campaign does have something of a story.The good: A very enjoyable game, finished to a very impressive standard. I especially liked the narrator’s voice acting (and voice acting IS a hobby horse on mine). For the completionists there are a number of challenges for every map. And personally the difficult is about right (easy-good). I rate this game: 7/10 Meaning positively good. Nearly every element is fantastic. However the concept is old which I do not like to see in Indie. The game for me gets repetitive with few levels requiring path lying. I’d like to see a “Double-Speed, Fast Forward” since I have to sit through most of the bloody game and I think the demo REALLY showed what this game could be, the full game feels a little ... bit of a backwards step.

Posted: January 3, 2014
												The addiction to Defense Grid builds as you play. First it's simply to beat each level. Then it is to beat each level without losing a single core. Then you begin to focus on improving your score. From there, you want to beat your friends scores, and of course, try to achieve all the achievements. But always, you will replay to polish your layout, your design, change your towers to see what works better, and try to figure out why you never seem to use Tower Type X (Fire, Concussion, etc).This is a great game with endless hours of playtime, further fed by the DLCs.You'll soon be waiting with bated breath for Defense Grid 2!

												I see the players who've spent hundreds of hours on this game and I can...I can really understand it. This isn't just one of the best tower defense games ever made, it's one of the best games ever made, period. It all adds up to a truly nailbiting experience, with just enough brain-teasing frustration to make you feel accomplished once you beat a campaign.It's a superb example of what game designers can accomplish by layering simple gameplay systems on top of each other, and fine-tuning through play balancing. Posted: July 14, 2014
												Defense Grid has everything that you might not expect from a tower defense game: original gameplay, a polished interface, great artwork and visuals, and even some nice voice acting. It also has the things that you probably would expect, like an assortment of different towers that may be upgraded, different types of enemies to defend against, and a variety of levels in which to try out particular strategies.In Defense Grid, you must defend your planet from an old, forgotten enemy. You take control of a dormant defense grid to fend off these alien invaders. Unlike many other tower defense games, the goal is not simply to stop the enemies from reaching the end of their path. Rather, you must prevent the aliens from stealing your power cores, which reside in a special housing. Thus each alien will walk from a starting point to the power core housing, and then to the exit. In many levels you have the option of shaping the aliens' paths by placing towers in their way.The cores provide an interesting addition to the gameplay. If an alien carrying a stolen core is killed, the core will slowly float back to its housing unless it gets intercepted by another alien. Keeping your cores in their housing allows you to collect additional "interest" on your resources, which can be used to buy and upgrade more towers. A particular core can trade hands many times, so even with a long and deadly path of towers, a large enough swarm of aliens will manage to get a core through if you aren't careful. You only need to keep one core protected to win a particular level, but saving all of the cores is necessary to get a silver or gold medal and a high score.The game features 10 different types of towers, 15 types of enemies, and 20 levels. There are also a number of DLC packs which offer additional levels. Each level also has a number of challenge modes which can be unlocked. These challenges often mix up the gameplay, such as by restricting which types of towers you may buy, or by altering the aliens' direction, and so on.But the most striking feature of the game is its presentation. Tower defense veterans may be used to playing Flash games with crude graphics in their web browsers, but Defense Grid's production values are comparable to most other high quality commercial games. The graphics, sound, interface, and level design were all executed very well, and there is enough content to last quite a few hours. The plot is fairly minimal, but it features a main character who has a surprising level of personality.You really shouldn't miss this one. Defense Grid offers the best of tower defense, whether you're new to the genre or an already avid fan. I highly recommend it.

												This is a superior Tower Defence game that rewards tactics and preparation. Starting with a gentle learning curve (and one of the few flaws of the game is that the earlier levels act as tutorials which hampers their replay value) it introduces you to an array of towers and tactics, each with their own advatanges and disadvantages against the diverse array of aliens that you would place them to kill.The gameplay mechanics, as befits the genre, are simple: you place towers alongside or in the way of the enemie's path to prevent them passing. Simple to grasp but, with an array of both towers at your disposal and enemies conspiring against you, tricky to master. Many times you find yourself going to earlier save points within a level or restarting it to try a different combination or placement.The sounds are good and the graphics all of a piece and attractive enough. The in game commentary and voice over can get a little annoying sometimes, but does add personality to the proceedings.

Posted: January 24, 2014
												This is a truly fun game. I really like the tower defense genre, but I am more drawn to games that look and play like this one. With a more real-world look and sci-fi atmosphere and story. Rather than the more fantasy oriented games with magical abilities, and cartoonish look. I like Fletcher, with his British accent. He is the AI that helps you on every stage. He operates the defense system and processes the the remains of destroyed aliens into resources for you to build and upgrade the towers. You never see him but his voice always encourages you and he provides an interesting plot for the game. You can see I have a ridiculous number of hours in this game - but that is because I became rather obsessed with playing a perfect game on as many stages as I could. For that you need to play through the stage without allowing any power cores to be stolen by the aliens. To accomplish that I would quit a game once the aliens got through my towers with a couple of cores, and then revise my strategy and start over. The amazing thing was on some of the perfect games that I played, there were still 50 or 60 thousand games on the leader board with higher scores than mine! Getting all of the DLC for this game greatly adds to the playing time by adding new stages and plots including one that had the voice of GLADOS from Portal! And there is replayability by playing the same stages with different circumstances and goals. Like playing the standard storyline stage with the alien entry and exit points reversed. Some of these are very difficult, like the Super Grinder mode which has 99 waves of aliens, instead of 20 -30 waves. THis game has very few weak points, and I'm looking forward to Defense Grid 2!

												Well executed tower defense game. Posted: July 3, 2011
												Defense Grid is without a doubt my most favorite tower defense game that I've ever played.  I'm biased against laser towers (but others love them), but I like how most of the towers actually have a purpose and the game lets you choose what strategy you want.  Multiple solutions exist for almost all stages unless you're doing the ultra-difficult challenge modes like "Out of Bullets" and "Green Towers Only".I will admit that I am biased toward Defense Grid, as this game let me go to the Portal 2 launch party, so it'll always be a little special to me.  I spoke to the developers and they are incredibly nice people.  One more fact:  This is one of the few modern games that was released on the PC first and then ported to the console.

Posted: January 14, 2014
												Hell yes! One of the best tower defense games i've ever played. Excellent graphics, great sound, interesting aliens to combat, fantastic, innovative and imaginative levels with multiple ways to finish them (not all but most of them). Towers are also very well made, they give the user a good feedback on what they do and how effective they are and best of all, their placement and upgrading is incredibly straight forward and easy to use (with grid based placement), so gameplay itself is a real joy.There are tons of levels with the stock game, but i highly recommend buying all the expansions and DLC's. I've bought and played the extra maps as they were released and they were well worth it.Cons or dislikes? If i'm truly honest, i can't think of a single one. Maybe that they aren't making new missions anymore (i'd even pay for them like i did before). That's about the only critic i have for this game.So, if you feel a need for some puzzle alien shooting in a tower defense type of a game, look no further, because this is it. The mother of all tower defense games. Say whatever you want, i think the game is absolutely amazing, great looking and just plain fun.

												I've been an "almost a fan" of tower defense games for a long time. Either they were too hard or required too much micro management to master. Defense Grid however is a great game. Posted: July 4, 2011
												Defense Grid is a brilliant game of its kind.  Build a maze of horrors that no rat can survive!  OK, it's actually aliens trying to steal power cores and destroy your computer AI pal or something.  The alien types are many and varied, as are the different towers you can build, of course.  Do you rely on machine guns?  Flamethrowers?  Long range cannon?  Time warp towers?  Lasers?  These and many more are deployed strategically and in interesting tactical combination to ensure the worst possible time for the alien invaders.  I would recommend this game without hesitation as a solid $20 title.  The list price of $9.99 is a steal and if you can get it on sale after that, oh brother.  Don't wait another day to pick up this great game.

Posted: January 5, 2014
												Defense Grid: Awakening is a nice Clean and tidy Tower Defense Game.Its Maps are divided into quadratic fields where you can build the Towers. It has 20 Levels from the get go, various DLC`s and Community Maps, so on the scope of the Game there is nothing Bad to say.There is a rather expendable Story for every Map, but additionally there all sorts of Mods (for example Reverse Level or Horde Mode).The Level design varies a bit, there are Maps with wide open Arias where you can build your own Tower Maze to your Hearts Content, but also more Levels where you are given are very Limited set of fields to build. And so the Difficulty and Strategy fluctuates quiet a bit. I would not say that its a difficult Game to beat, but to Master every Level on Gold there is quiet a bit of Level study and learning if and when which Wave of Enemy's is coming.Pro:-Level variety-Enemy variety-Easy to learn, hard to masterContra:-Learning Curve has spikesSo clear Recommendation. Especially for this price (Game is in addition often discounted).

Posted: July 4, 2011
												DG is really the rolls royce of tower defence games. There is really not much out there that can hold a candle to it in terms of quality, both of gameplay and presentation, and story.It has a reasonable learning curve and will hold your hand for a while but many of the levels can prove quite challenging and you will likely need to come back to them, to conquer them.One of the best bits is that most of my gaming opportunities come in small bites of time, like 20mins or half an hour. This game is ideal for that sort of slot, with a decent amount of fun and payoff in that time.I do like to give something a try, see how it goes, then perhaps come away for a day or so and while you're at work, or on the train, you think, "What would have happened if I had tried this or that, or put that turret there?" and then you can go back and try it.  So I love to try new approaches and see if I can come up with new ideas to defend the levels better. or just try new ideas.All in all it's an awesome little game, and likely worth far more than you'll pay for it!

Posted: December 22, 2014
												This is one of the best games that I have ever played. The graphics are great, the sound is great, and the number of available missions (and variants) is great. There are a vast amount of different approaches that can be taken with most of the missions, and just upgrading all of your guns usually will not work. The medals, leaderboard scoring, and the achievements provide something to strive for. There is quite possibly over 100 hours of game play in all of the core and DLC missions combined, so getting this title on sale would be an absolute steal, and well worth it at regular price.

Posted: December 21, 2014
												Of all the tower defense games I've seen and played, this is the most polished and professional.Each scenario is well balanced with enough variety in towers and placement, as well as game modes per level, to keep things interesting. Each of the 10 or so towers you can build are unique enough that even late game, you are using a wide variety; there's no "best" tower. Every tower can also be upgraded for more damage/faster fire rate/increased range.Leaderboards are done extremely well in this game. Your score is ranked worldwide, but then you also see your friends and their scores. This gives it a much more competative feel since you can see how you measure up to your friends per scenario.The story isn't anything fantastic, but compared to other tower defense games (which usually have no story), it's good.There is no multi-player and no map editor. Check Defense Grid 2 if interested in these.This game is my benchmark for other tower defense games, and most fall far short of this one.

												Excellent game. On each level you have to place a variety of defensive towers, choosing the position and type of tower carefully thanks to your limited budget. As waves of enemies try to cross the map, your towers will (hopefully) wipe them out, earning you extra funds which you can spend on ... more towers. The strategy element is strong - do you place lots of cheap towers, or keep replacing a handful of towers with more powerful (and very expensive) upgrades? The waves of aliens are varied enough to keep you guessing, and there are dozens of levels to play through.

Posted: December 27, 2011
												I picked this game up when it was pretty new and keep finding reasons to come back to it. I've found it to be one of the best tower defense games I've ever played, perhaps even the best.Gameplay wise there's a lot of variety in the levels and how you can play them, varying in difficulty from pushover to devilishly hard. There's just enough types of towers to give you a lot of options but not enough for there to be any real overlap in their roles. The voice acting, while limited to just one character, (two if you count the "You Monster" DLC) is top notch.In addition to all this the game has gotten plenty of love from the developer over time with bug fixes and DLC with new maps and gameplay. The "You Monster" DLC also has some gameplay very different to anything else so far.Oh and there's a demo, so check that out!

Posted: July 23, 2011
												This is a fairly solid tower defense game. You build towers on strategic spots on a map to prevent aliens from stealing cores. There is a  large assortment of towers to choose from, and you will need to learn the purpose of most of them to do well.This game has a handful of issues. The strategies that it offers are interesting, but they don't seem to be as effective as they should be. The game offers that you build towers in the way of aliens to shape their paths. If they are not given a choice, they will pass throught the shield of the nearest tower. Unfortunately, the AI tends to bug out and ignore this, passing through shields despite there being another unobstructed path. Also, certain aliens seem to have implausibly high resistances to damage. More than once I have had a line of cannons firing a storm of shells at tiny poorly armored units and fail to kill them. More than once I've had badly damaged heavy armor pass by multiple towers of any kind and slip away at the last core

Posted: March 24, 2011
												Defense Grid is a tower defense game, meaning that you strategically place different types of towers to damage enemies as they move past, occasionally using towers to determine their paths through the level. Defense Grid introduces nothing new to the genre, offering little more than the basics: building, upgrading, and selling towers. That said, I'm a fan of tower defense games, and this game does provide a good challenge. The levels do get pretty hard, especially if you're looking to get the achievements.I think the biggest problem with this game is the steep learning curve, which could be a problem if you haven't played a tower defense game before. I would've also liked a little more variety in the maps, or maybe a few more of them, at least.I've enjoyed Defense Grid, but then again, it's my type of game. I'd recommend it to anyone that enjoys strategy. Everyone else can pass on it. I think it's worth it for $10, barely, but it's worth waiting for it to go on sale.

												Oh my god this is the best tower defence game ever made.The graphics, voice acting, and sound effects are all top notch. The soundtrack is epic and perfectly compliments your destructive death trap.But what makes this tower defence game more strategic than any other is the ability to redirect your enemies' paths with your towers. Blocking off pathways and having them adapt to find the shortest route possible adds an amazing amount of depth to the game. Nothing feels better than finishing your grand death-trap maze consisting of gun towers, cannons, flamethowers, lasers, temporal slowdown fields, tesla towers, clusterbombs, and missile launchers.Oh, and there's Portal DLC with GLaDOS.

Posted: July 5, 2013
												If you are ever looking for a classic tower defense done right, try this out; there is a demo. The gameplay is perfect and the map variation and challenges are a lot of fun. There is a great balance of towers and enemy types.  The only bad thing is the dialogue, which is good and often funny, but can get annoying as the same lines are constantly repeated.The You Monster DLC is probably the best part of the game. This DLC is not much like the original game in the way the levels are set up, but the dialogue is great and the levels are very challenging even to experienced players.  The Resurgence map packs and Containment DLC aren't much different in style from the original game, and the story isn't interesting, but if you loved the base game and want more, they are fun.

Posted: November 28, 2013
												Back when I used to play many RTS titles, one of my favorite things to do was to build a defensive network with multiple types of turrets, just waiting for the enemy to throw what they had at me.  Then later I found 'Defense Grid', a game that takes this Defensive Network concept and makes an entire game out of it.  And it actually works excellently, perhaps better than any other entry in this 'Defense Tower' genre.  Each level is challenging (sans the first) but by going through the motions, it's fully possible to work out a working strategy for all situations.  But most of all, it's highly addictive and you genuinely feel a level of accomplishment when you beat a level.  It's neither hand-holding nor frustrating.  It even has a story, more or less.  Highly recommended.

Posted: December 27, 2011
												One of the best tower defense games I've played. Totally addictive!I played Defense Grid: The Awakening back in 2011 and spent a lot of time replaying all the levels to get a gold medal in all the levels. I'm now revisiting it again in 2014 and I've found its still as good as the first time around but they've added so much now along with a DLC if you're willing to spend $5.The different modes give numerous ways to play the different levels. Some will require you to play without gun and cannon turrets where other modes will give you a 10 tower limit or green towers only. Green towers being the tower without any upgrades. So this game will keep you busy for hours upon hours trying to get a gold medal. There being Bronze, Silver and Gold for each level.The original Awakening campaign sports 20 levels each with anything from 4-10 different modes to get gold on. If you enjoy getting achievements there is one to get 150 gold medals on the Awakening campaign alone. Then there are additional campaigns of Borderlands, Resurgence and Portal (You Monster) which have 5 additional levels each and of course the DLC called containment.You can see the hours racking up here. So in regards to value for money it is definitely a good buy.

Posted: March 18, 2011
												Do you fancy tower defense games? Well this title goes one step further than the usual TD game and requires some extra care in placement of your towers. Posted: May 25, 2015
												I had a lot of problems over several years trying to sink my teeth into this game.  It's fast-paced, the levels are very long, there's no saving mid-level, and the strategy necessary is very complex.  It's been a grind, but ultimately a rewarding one, and certainly the best on the tower defense market.  However, you can also sometimes cheat and use the mechanics to "juggle" waves around your towers infinitely, which is a little lame.Nevertheless, the features in this game are unparalleled, and so are the story elements.  Don't give up.  Grind it out and iterate on your strategies.

Posted: February 19, 2014
												Emotional attachment to a character in a tower defense game?  Especially one that you never get to see on screen, and all development is done purely via the narrative?  Oh, and let's also make that character an AI.  Sound unlikely?  I never would have thought it would be done either - for that matter, I never expected a developer to even bother trying.  But in "Defense Grid: The Awakening", the narrative AI who guides you through the game really DOES develop a character that can bring an emotional attachment towards "him" even without any onscreen presence - especially towards the later levels of the story.  And it's a pretty cool tower defense game in its own right, too.  Strongly recommend checking it out for anyone who likes TD games, OR who wants to see an example of how to develop a seemingly impersonal character through narrative alone.  Well done to Hidden Path Entertainment with this one.

												Defense Grid: The Awakening is, at its core, a puzzle game. It's a good one, but the various levels are not nearly as free-form as you might initially believe. Many levels can be beaten in multiple ways, but many levels favor a particular layout of towers. After playing through a dozen levels or so, you realize certain consistent strategies to victory: make the path the aliens travel as long as you can, and build a lot of cannon towers. Yes, there are nuances beyond that, but the strategy isn't really all that deep.But that's okay. It's an easy game to play in 30-minute chunks; the lack of save game slots (as opposed to the acceptable-but-not-ideal checkpoint system) is annoying, but mildly so. (Although, to be fair, that might be just my own over-saving nature speaking.) It's rewarding, pretty, nicely paced, and has a decent enough plot.I bought it for something like $2.49. At that price, a great bargain.

Posted: December 10, 2010
												Great little game, with more depth than what meets the eyes at first. This is an evolution of the basic tower defense maps from warcraft 3, but a lot more refined. There is a decent choice of towers, all balanced so they each have their applications and role. And there is also the local (your friends) and global score tracking that adds tons of replay value. It keeps you constantly wanting to go back to each level to try and come up with better, more innovative and cost efficient solutions.It has also some great ideas like savepoints you can backtrack to with a touch of a button (backspace), the "interest" mechanism that lets you earn more score if you find a good defense and have spare, unspent ressources, and so on. A fine gem of a game, highly recommended.

Posted: November 19, 2010
												What's better than killing defenseless zombies rushing towards you? Aliens walking in straight line, while being mauled endlessly by the defensive measures you have placed in advance. Yes, Defense Grid is a typical tower defense game, where nameless characterless pixels try to move on the screen to steal your resources and making it out alive. Your mission is to stop them, and your arsenal are towers that are equipped with either gatling gun, flame-throwers, tesla coil and missiles amongst others. With an apt in-game voiced commentary, there isn't a dull moment while you keep the alien population in check. Defense Grid stands out especially in the ability to shape the paths for the aliens, challenging the players to best themselves on repeated attempts on the same map, by making the alien's suicidal mission even more grueling each time around. With a number of challenges like poisonous cores, Defense Grid is a title that offers hours and hours of entertainment to the faithful.

Posted: April 11, 2012
												Surpringly very fun. I mean I've been a fan of tower defence for a while, but even still.Standard fare tower defence, different tower types, some are better against certain creeps, yadda yadda.The main point of interest for me was you can place towers on the grid where the creeps walk, and direct them through a maze of towers. But you can't just place them willy-nilly, you can only place them in specific areas, which lends to the strategy of tower defence. Often, you'll have many small squares of these bridged, with not all spaces on the square buildable. You have to direct the creeps in the most efficient way, but of course, building towers requires resources. Setting these mazes up is a challenge - a fun challenge.Oh and your little robot companion buddy AI thing has some amazing quips. I did find myself laughing and saying to it "you're terrible, you know that?", but that's what makes him so good! It's like listening to Stephen Fry. Even the bad jokes are good.

Posted: January 4, 2014
												If saving the planet from alien hoardes, assisted by a raspberry loving computer and some towers with guns and stuff on them  sounds like your idea of fun... well, this is the game for you!Having played the missions on the original "The Awakening" on more than one occasion, I'm happy to say that I still find Defense Grid an enjoyable way to spend a quiet afternoon.Ok it's Tower Defense and doesn't really do more than that, but it's challenging enough not to need to.The amount of levels is generous and even though it's pretty much "rinse and repeat" every level, the design of each map does make you think a bit, and the difference between good and bad tower placement makes some of the maps really quite interesting, as correctly placing towers will allow you to send the aliens running twice the distance for their beloved "cores" passed your deadly "towers of doom".Graphically the game sits in a 'sort of' fixed 3d retro isometric type view, which is more than adequate for the game mechanic and does it's job wellThis game also has a lot of DLC which i have yet to investigate, but it all looks pretty promising.All in all it's a pleasant experience and I would definitely recommend it ito Tower Defense fans.

												The pinnacle of Tower Defense; Defense Grid nails the genre.  The presentation value is high with sleek visuals and a well-crafted narrator that guides you through the game's universe, but what really matters is gameplay, and Defense Grid nails it in the campaign and the many, many diverse modes it packs along. If you like strategy in general and TD especially, you'll want all the DLC, but definitely don't miss You Monster, because the only thing this game was really missing in the first run was GLaDOS. Posted: July 12, 2012
												Defense Grid: The Awakening is hands down the best tower defense game I have ever played. It takes all the conventions you would expect from a good traditional TD game such as different types of upgradable towers, different enemies with their own stengths and weaknesses, and multiple stategies and game modes for large replayability. All this packaged into a budget title that feels like a AAA game and you have a game that simply can't be passed up. Add to this already great game the fact that there is a Portal themed DLC!

Posted: May 3, 2013
												A traditional tower defense game (this one is somewhat the originator of the gaming concept). You setup defensive checkpoints or "towers" along a grid and hope you've laid out enough firepower to stop the swarms of aliens coming to destroy you.

Posted: November 28, 2013
												This is a great tower defense game - possibly the best on Steam.The controls are very intuitive, the towers are diverse and useful, and there are plenty of game modes for replayability.Towers range from the typical machine gun tower to AOE damage towers to utility towers like the slow-movement-speed tower and more.This game has some unique features that differentiate it from other tower defense games. Checkpoints occur at various intervals throughout each mission and the player can simply hit "backspace" to return to the previous checkpoint (or hit backspace multiple times to go to a specific checkpoint). An "orbital laser" ability allows you to destroy large groups of enemies at one time as a sort of "last ditch effort". This ability is on a long cooldown, but lets you get out of a tight spot quickly.

Posted: July 3, 2011
												The premise is simple, a slew of alien baddies enter the map in waves and travel the shortest path to steal your power cores, you must build a maze/grid of towers to stop them. You gain more resources by killing the aliens, resources you desperately need to upgrade or build more towers to kill the ever increasing new waves of aliens. Every game is basically a race to figure out the optimum defensive grid. After you beat each level, harder varied challenge versions of the level open up. I never felt frustration or tedium while playing and replaying the levels until I was able to figure out the optimal playthrough, and the balance and pacing was really spot on. It was very fun, addictive, and well worth my money, and the time I spent playing through it almost three times.Defense Grid: The Awakening is hands down the best tower defense game I have ever played. It is addictive, fun, worthwhile and ultimately fulfilling. Buy it now.

Posted: November 28, 2013
												Back when I used to play many RTS titles, one of my favorite things to do was to build a defensive network with multiple types of turrets, just waiting for the enemy to throw what they had at me.  Then later I found 'Defense Grid', a game that takes this Defensive Network concept and makes an entire game out of it.  And it actually works excellently, perhaps better than any other entry in this 'Defense Tower' genre.  Each level is challenging (sans the first) but by going through the motions, it's fully possible to work out a working strategy for all situations.  But most of all, it's highly addictive and you genuinely feel a level of accomplishment when you beat a level.  It's neither hand-holding nor frustrating.  It even has a story, more or less.  Highly recommended.

												     Defense Grid: The Awakening is a good game, but it is also not exactly a game that I would buy outside of it being bundled with another game or discounted. The game has nice visuals, fun gameplay, and plenty of challenges to keep you occupied.      But the problem with this game is what it is, a tower defense game. Tower defense games are everywhere, and you can find better ones that cost nothing and can be played in your browser. The only thing this game has going for it in comparison to an in browser TD game is its graphics, and those aren't exactly that exciting.      Overall, if you find out theres a game bundle or its on a heavy discount try it out. It isn't a bad game, it's just another tower defense game. But you have to pay for it.

Posted: October 1, 2014
												I never really cared for tower defense games... then I played Defense Grid and it became one of my favorite games to play on PC. I love Defense Grid so much that I tried a couple other tower defense games but all they made me want to do is play more Defense Grid because in my opinion, it just does tower defense better than any anything else. DG has such a great asthetic that it was not intimidating to start playing for a total tower defense noob, in fact, the voice acting of the AI narrator is actually pretty charming and it was one of the things that made me prefer DG to others. The one feature that is a must have for me after playing DG aside from the fun bit of strategy involved but using your own towers on most levels to block and elongate the paths of the alien forces before they steal your cores, is the replay button. I feel the need to perfect every level (OCD I guess) so I love that if I miscalculated my defenses I can just hit "backspace" and immediately keep playing from the last checkpoint, it may seem cheap to a purist player, but I don't care, it makes me happy like when I was a kid and I was about to lose a game of checkers to my little sister and I would just flip over the board, only in DG the board resets in an instant and I get to try again until I win without letting any of those lousy aliens take any of my cores because each time they do I die a little inside (why is that? what is wrong with me?). Anyway, I love the game and would recommend it to anyone because even if you don't think you would like a tower defense game, this is the one game to play before you are sure, if it doesn't turn you, you cannot be turned.

												I bought this game with all DLC's. I had just got into "Tower Defense"  games recently through the purchase of Sanctum & Sanctum 2. I like both those games alot. They have a FPS aspect to those games, pause between Waves. etc. And I like that......... But after searching for Tower Defense games here on Steam, looking and  reading about alot of them, I chose to buy Defense Grid: The Awakening. I have not been disappointed!!!  NOTE: DG2 is already out, but i still chose to check out the first game in the series,There is no pause between waves, you can buy/upgrade towers during the whole level. The waves are shown coming on a HUD at the top of screen when new waves are coming along with audio warnings.. Different Towers = Different Effects on Different Aliens etc,, Family Friendly, no cursing that I've heard etc. No blood. Just weapon towers against aliens etc. Strategy Oriented, FUN!!! Also, great interface,  good graphics, fun gameplay, and as I discovered, you CAN even beat the hard maps!1 :)Rcommended!!! c0AXP.S. Looking forward to my purchase of DG2!!!!

Posted: July 4, 2011
												Defense Grid is a well-realized, single-player tower defense style game.  It mixes fixed-path and mazing levels with a solid variety of towers and enemy types.  No tower feels useless or overly-necessary and there is never just one sucessful build solution for a level.  There are also many interesting rule variations you can use to inspire creativity in your design.  All of this is wrapped in some solid voice acting and a story about the contributions the elderly can still make in our society when they are past their prime.

Posted: October 2, 2013
												Released several years ago, Defense Grid was one of the first big indie hits on Steam as well as one of the greatest tower defense games of all time. A game that is easy to learn, and difficult to master, it starts out pretty simple and limiting at first, but by the later levels, there are many options to how you set up your route, what weapons to use, and how you use them. The game also boosts some solid visuals, a suprisingly interesting story and main character, and good replayability on all but the initial few tutorial-like missions. Highly recommended!

All the DLC is worth the cheap price because it adds some new levels to play and ways to think about defending crystals in the game. Only problem for me was that there was no sound on my PC with Windows 7, and I suffered for a while until a good patch was released, so it was stable enough to play, but I think the game is in working order. It will run on almost any system, so it’s not a graphics hog, yet it still can be a pretty game on lower settings. Enjoy

Posted: April 11, 2012
												Surpringly very fun. I mean I've been a fan of tower defence for a while, but even still.Standard fare tower defence, different tower types, some are better against certain creeps, yadda yadda.The main point of interest for me was you can place towers on the grid where the creeps walk, and direct them through a maze of towers. But you can't just place them willy-nilly, you can only place them in specific areas, which lends to the strategy of tower defence. Often, you'll have many small squares of these bridged, with not all spaces on the square buildable. You have to direct the creeps in the most efficient way, but of course, building towers requires resources. Setting these mazes up is a challenge - a fun challenge.Oh and your little robot companion buddy AI thing has some amazing quips. I did find myself laughing and saying to it "you're terrible, you know that?", but that's what makes him so good! It's like listening to Stephen Fry. Even the bad jokes are good.

												     Defense Grid: The Awakening is a good game, but it is also not exactly a game that I would buy outside of it being bundled with another game or discounted. The game has nice visuals, fun gameplay, and plenty of challenges to keep you occupied.      But the problem with this game is what it is, a tower defense game. Tower defense games are everywhere, and you can find better ones that cost nothing and can be played in your browser. The only thing this game has going for it in comparison to an in browser TD game is its graphics, and those aren't exactly that exciting.      Overall, if you find out theres a game bundle or its on a heavy discount try it out. It isn't a bad game, it's just another tower defense game. But you have to pay for it.

Posted: February 11, 2014
												While most tower defense games are Just the same "use X to survive X amount of rounds and then preceed to the next round to repeat" Defense Grid changes it up. Along the game you start to get More Blueprints inorder to make New towers while the story Preceeds. - Yes, this game has a STORY! A Rare occurence with games like these. Besides playing the Story mode of each map, You can also play different versions of the same map with a new twist. There is also the "Community Maps" That has new stuff added each time, also there are Mini games that you can do if you wanna take a break. Before the DG2 Kickstarter, there was a Console from the PotatoFoolsDay Portal 2 ARG. I think there might be some way to get it back but i have no idea.Overall, Defense Grid: The Awakening is a Breath of Fresh air for the Genre and this is a game i seriously recommend.

Posted: February 10, 2014
												This stayed on my Steam list as a hidden diamond for so long.As far as tower defense games go this is one of the better ones if not one of the best ones (if best being superlative could have multiples) The games is beautiful to look at it does not feel dated even 5 years after its release. The levels are also very varied and interesting there are loads of avenues of replayability either by the set modes or just simply by making things up in your head like this round I will try and win just using gun towers.However i will put a but in here aside from the positives of this game I will throw in one big negative in my viewpoint. There is not enough variety in the aliens and the towers themselves are neither negative or positive at taking out anything. I built up a bunch of teslas to take out bosses when I finally realized what a boss was (I was expecting something much bigger) my very basic cheapo turrets had wiped the floor with them long before they got to the tesla turrets which are supposed to be the boss killers (maybe some defensive bonuses could have been added to them to make other turrets less effective at them).But conclude on the good if you want a great tower defense game that will keep you busy and on your toes this is certainly a great purchase.

Posted: July 5, 2011
												As a big fan of tower defense games since they emerged, I've played many. Defense Grid: The Awakening is head and shoulders above every other of it's ilk. The core mechanics which make for a fun and challenging TD game are represented magnificently; maps are well designed and plentiful, ranging in difficulty from the sublime to the maddening. Pace and enemy flow are spot on, providing a challenge without becoming frustrating  and enemy variety demands careful consideration when placing towers. Upgrades for your towers can be bought using points earned killing the hordes of energy core stealing aliens and give the towers that extra punch required in later waves. For TD games I've never placed much importance on hi fidelity graphics, the game-play just doesn't demand it. Defence Grid however pulls out all the stops in it's designs and renders giving you a diverse line-up of uber cool aliens, towers and backgrounds. Defense Grid is THE shining example of the genre; a must buy for any fan.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2011
												This game is a re-enactment of the same war upon which The Lord Of The Rings: The Two Towers was based. What was it? The Tolkein War or something? Basically there are a lot of these little angry dude who wanted to invade but they had this tower to stop them. There were two towers: one with a big giant flame at the top that shoots lasers at the little guys to heat them up and make them take damage over time and another one with Magneto inside who would like shoot beams of magnetic energy at everything. What a cool guy Magneto was. He's the kind of villain you can really understand because he doesn't just go around destroying everything for fun. No, he does it because he's idealistic and the world isn't as just as he thinks it ought to be. And he's right. But then extra-bald Picard has to come in and use his diplomacy on Magneto, bringing his army of giant talking trees with him to show Magneto that the powers of good beat the powers of grey-area. LOTR is the bad ending to this game.

Posted: July 14, 2011
												Tower Defense with serious production values.  Defense Grid is Tower Defense polished to a mirror shine, with a story and DLC to boot.  Various enemies and swarms will keep you busy, while a huge number of towers will let you fine-tune the performance of your play to get higher scores.  The asthetic is clean, and makes all these high-tech towers really meld in to what's going on, while the normal campaign makes picking the game up easy even for those unfamiliar with Tower Defense.

Posted: February 8, 2013
												Best tower-defence game, bar none, IMO.Each tower is distinct and tactically useful regardless of how many others you unlock.The maps have great variety in paths and strategy: some will force you to spread yourself thin and optimize for cheap towers, some will give you limited options and really force you to make every tower count; others will make you front-load your defence while others force you defend on the back foot, some even force a rear-guard action of attacking the aliens as they retreat with their loot.The UI is clean and simple, with the friendliest checkpoint system ever invented with an "oops" button to immediately take you back through previous checkpoints, and a fast-forward button for those times when you need to speed ahead.Then there's the storytelling, beautiful voice acting with more than a dash of humour.And finally, if that isn't enough, every level has 4 to 5 different challenge modes that push you out of your comfort zone again.Buy it, and buy all the DLC, it's great value for money.

Posted: August 25, 2011
												Well, I hadn't really played tower defense games before this. Didn't exactly know the concept was essentially a more complicated version of the one casual game where the colored beads come in, and you have to shoot them with colored beads from your turrett to knock them out. Yeah pretty much that but with more turrets and bullets and flames for beads, and heartier beads with different varieties you have to kill off. A decent bit of fun and frustration trying to set up the right towers at the right time to not bone yourself later. While this is still the most polished of the Tower Defense games I've played, others have done far more for play variety and interesting mechanics to spice up the formula. Still good for a bit of fun, even if I'm not a fan of the half hearted addition of a score board to extend play. 4/5

Posted: July 12, 2016
												i want to say i really like this game , far better than the second one. as a matter of fact , dont even get the second one. it is not good at all. but my major problem with this game is the fact that there is no structure to the story. you can just skip to any map at any time. you dont need to earn your way by beating the current map. so to me it felt like the challenge had been taken away. and i didnt like that at all.and now when i go back to play it, its  like pick any map and play. i want to play the whole game again. but to do that i have to put myself through each sccessive map and then if i beat it i can pass to the next, even though i can pass to the next map anyway without beating it. its just not right. this style of game kinda takes away the whole point for me. Like i just opened it and would like to play it again , but the fact that every map is just available and there is no game criteria or structure to play.it takes the appeal away for me.so i just closed it and am going to play something else. cause it just isnt worth it to me. the makers of this game made a major mistake doing it like this in my opinion.

Posted: July 5, 2016
												How have I not written a review of this yet? I completely devoured this game.This is hands down one of my favourite tower defence games of all time. Everything about it is on point. Mechanics are good, with lots of varied tower types, and many different aliens, the stages are also quite varied in design, within the limitation of the game mechanics. Graphics and sound are quite good, yet still playable on my tablet (Atom Z3775-based).Which brings me to another point: it has touch support, and suffers little for it. Not quite as accurate as a mouse, which does result in some accidents, but it's mostly a matter of getting used to it.The voice acted story is excellent, both in terms of voice acting quality, and writing. It was a particularly nice element of this game, actually. The player's AI ally is amusing and endearing, while also delivering the game's "tutorial" elements.The gameplay is addicting, and the difficulty is fair, which led me to 100-percenting this game's achievements. Replay value is decent as well, with multiple strategies working well enough to pass most levels.The only thing that feels "off" is the degree to which some towers are either useless in a given level, or basically mandatory. Missile towers in particular, and the flying enemies they shoot down, seem like they're only in the game to be a backdoor means of draining resources away from your other defences. Not a huge issue overall, but the tower type could use some retooling (like they did in DG2).If you like the genre, I'd definitely recommend buying this, even at full price, no regrets.

Posted: July 5, 2013
												If you are ever looking for a classic tower defense done right, try this out; there is a demo. The gameplay is perfect and the map variation and challenges are a lot of fun. There is a great balance of towers and enemy types.  The only bad thing is the dialogue, which is good and often funny, but can get annoying as the same lines are constantly repeated.The You Monster DLC is probably the best part of the game. This DLC is not much like the original game in the way the levels are set up, but the dialogue is great and the levels are very challenging even to experienced players.  The Resurgence map packs and Containment DLC aren't much different in style from the original game, and the story isn't interesting, but if you loved the base game and want more, they are fun.

Posted: November 28, 2013
												Back when I used to play many RTS titles, one of my favorite things to do was to build a defensive network with multiple types of turrets, just waiting for the enemy to throw what they had at me.  Then later I found 'Defense Grid', a game that takes this Defensive Network concept and makes an entire game out of it.  And it actually works excellently, perhaps better than any other entry in this 'Defense Tower' genre.  Each level is challenging (sans the first) but by going through the motions, it's fully possible to work out a working strategy for all situations.  But most of all, it's highly addictive and you genuinely feel a level of accomplishment when you beat a level.  It's neither hand-holding nor frustrating.  It even has a story, more or less.  Highly recommended.

Posted: October 11, 2014
												I adore tower defence games, I've played a lot of them... and this one is, without doubt, the best of them all... It has astonishing diversity, across a huge number of levels, all incredibly well balanced... it's fiendishly difficult at times, and no matter how well you do, you're always left with the feeling that you could have done better... it really is a masterpiece of a game!!!That said... if you've never played DG, I would recommend you play DG2 first... if this game didn't exist, DG2 would be my #1... but it does, and if you play this one first, you may find DG2 to be a little disappointing... which would be a shame, because DG2 is great... it's just that this one is better...If you enjoy tower defence games at all... you simply must play Defense Grid... or you're missing out on the genre's finest achievement!!!

Posted: July 14, 2014
												Defense Grid has everything that you might not expect from a tower defense game: original gameplay, a polished interface, great artwork and visuals, and even some nice voice acting. It also has the things that you probably would expect, like an assortment of different towers that may be upgraded, different types of enemies to defend against, and a variety of levels in which to try out particular strategies.In Defense Grid, you must defend your planet from an old, forgotten enemy. You take control of a dormant defense grid to fend off these alien invaders. Unlike many other tower defense games, the goal is not simply to stop the enemies from reaching the end of their path. Rather, you must prevent the aliens from stealing your power cores, which reside in a special housing. Thus each alien will walk from a starting point to the power core housing, and then to the exit. In many levels you have the option of shaping the aliens' paths by placing towers in their way.The cores provide an interesting addition to the gameplay. If an alien carrying a stolen core is killed, the core will slowly float back to its housing unless it gets intercepted by another alien. Keeping your cores in their housing allows you to collect additional "interest" on your resources, which can be used to buy and upgrade more towers. A particular core can trade hands many times, so even with a long and deadly path of towers, a large enough swarm of aliens will manage to get a core through if you aren't careful. You only need to keep one core protected to win a particular level, but saving all of the cores is necessary to get a silver or gold medal and a high score.The game features 10 different types of towers, 15 types of enemies, and 20 levels. There are also a number of DLC packs which offer additional levels. Each level also has a number of challenge modes which can be unlocked. These challenges often mix up the gameplay, such as by restricting which types of towers you may buy, or by altering the aliens' direction, and so on.But the most striking feature of the game is its presentation. Tower defense veterans may be used to playing Flash games with crude graphics in their web browsers, but Defense Grid's production values are comparable to most other high quality commercial games. The graphics, sound, interface, and level design were all executed very well, and there is enough content to last quite a few hours. The plot is fairly minimal, but it features a main character who has a surprising level of personality.You really shouldn't miss this one. Defense Grid offers the best of tower defense, whether you're new to the genre or an already avid fan. I highly recommend it.

Posted: July 14, 2014
												One of the best tower defense games. Although some towers are more useful than others, there is no "god" tower, which you can just spam the level full and win. Different enemies require different tactics. Levels are mostly "path"-levels, but some levels allow you to decide where to guide the enemies to get the most out of the route "un-optimization". Posted: June 30, 2014
												This game has been a long time favorite, and is a great addition for anyone who enjoys the tower defense genre of gaming. The levels are simple in design, yet force you to think of how you want to lay out your design carefully. Some levels push this a bit farther, giving you multiple ways to maze and build. This really comes into focus during the later maps of the Story Mode, where the enemies have literally a dozen pathing options.On top of the typical story mode there are also many different challenge modes for each map, giving hours of enjoyment. Modes include: Grinder and Super Grinder, 99 waves that get progressively harder as you go; Green Towers Only, where you can't upgrade your towers at all; Story Reversed, that swaps the direction the enemies travel; and much more.There are also a few extra campaigns available through DLC, as well as community driven content with tons of maps to try out. All in all, it's a very solid pickup for any of you Tower Defense fans out there, and an enjoyable game all around.

Posted: July 1, 2014
												This game defines the tower defense genre for me.tl;dr: 10/10, will play againIn terms of dollars per hour of entertainment, this is one of the best financial decisions I ever made. :)Disliked:- The story line is a bit cheesy.  But then, I don't play tower defense for storyline.- Absolutely critical hints are given as pop-ups throughout the game, which can be easy to miss.  (Looks pointedly at the backspace and 'F' keys.)Liked:- The game is a pure tower defense.- The challenge level of the game is excellent.  There are maps with no-lose easy modes, and maps for which getting the gold medal will require trial and failure of many different strategies - which means when you finally find a working strategy, you feel like a genius.  Really excellent attention to level balance must have been paid at some point.- The checkpointing/back up to checkpoint mechanic is essential.  I didn't know it existed for the first tens of hours I played the game, and enjoyment went way up when a friend told me about it.- The fast forward capability 'F' is awesome.- The game is pretty.  You don't need absurd gaming hardware to enjoy the visuals.  And, if you have absurd gaming hardware, the visuals look great.  I have midrange hardware and the game is beautiful to behold.

Posted: November 28, 2013
												This is a great tower defense game - possibly the best on Steam.The controls are very intuitive, the towers are diverse and useful, and there are plenty of game modes for replayability.Towers range from the typical machine gun tower to AOE damage towers to utility towers like the slow-movement-speed tower and more.This game has some unique features that differentiate it from other tower defense games. Checkpoints occur at various intervals throughout each mission and the player can simply hit "backspace" to return to the previous checkpoint (or hit backspace multiple times to go to a specific checkpoint). An "orbital laser" ability allows you to destroy large groups of enemies at one time as a sort of "last ditch effort". This ability is on a long cooldown, but lets you get out of a tight spot quickly.

Posted: July 3, 2011
												The premise is simple, a slew of alien baddies enter the map in waves and travel the shortest path to steal your power cores, you must build a maze/grid of towers to stop them. You gain more resources by killing the aliens, resources you desperately need to upgrade or build more towers to kill the ever increasing new waves of aliens. Every game is basically a race to figure out the optimum defensive grid. After you beat each level, harder varied challenge versions of the level open up. I never felt frustration or tedium while playing and replaying the levels until I was able to figure out the optimal playthrough, and the balance and pacing was really spot on. It was very fun, addictive, and well worth my money, and the time I spent playing through it almost three times.Defense Grid: The Awakening is hands down the best tower defense game I have ever played. It is addictive, fun, worthwhile and ultimately fulfilling. Buy it now.

Posted: November 29, 2014
												If the game is on sale and you like tower defense games you should give it a try. Please note that there are some things that DG makes different compared to other tower defense games ... - No pause button to help plan your strategy (you can press backspace though to reload a previous checkpoint)- No timer telling you when exactly your orbital cannon will come off cooldown - Mobs can walk through towers in case you manage to block their path by accident - While games like Sanctum 2 or Prime World:Defenders tell you which path the aliens will take and how placed towers will affect them, Defense Grid doesn't (which results in lots of reloading -.-)So it's a 78/100

Posted: December 9, 2012
												Excellent game. On each level you have to place a variety of defensive towers, choosing the position and type of tower carefully thanks to your limited budget. As waves of enemies try to cross the map, your towers will (hopefully) wipe them out, earning you extra funds which you can spend on ... more towers. The strategy element is strong - do you place lots of cheap towers, or keep replacing a handful of towers with more powerful (and very expensive) upgrades? The waves of aliens are varied enough to keep you guessing, and there are dozens of levels to play through.

Posted: November 19, 2010
												What's better than killing defenseless zombies rushing towards you? Aliens walking in straight line, while being mauled endlessly by the defensive measures you have placed in advance. Yes, Defense Grid is a typical tower defense game, where nameless characterless pixels try to move on the screen to steal your resources and making it out alive. Your mission is to stop them, and your arsenal are towers that are equipped with either gatling gun, flame-throwers, tesla coil and missiles amongst others. With an apt in-game voiced commentary, there isn't a dull moment while you keep the alien population in check. Defense Grid stands out especially in the ability to shape the paths for the aliens, challenging the players to best themselves on repeated attempts on the same map, by making the alien's suicidal mission even more grueling each time around. With a number of challenges like poisonous cores, Defense Grid is a title that offers hours and hours of entertainment to the faithful.

Posted: February 7, 2015
												Defense Grid : The Awakening has anything I could wish from a Tower Defense : - a variety of multipurpose towers with strengths and weaknesses, that can upgraded and sold, - a level layout that allows you to carefully plan where and when to build towers,- a diversity of enemies with strengths and weaknesses, that always challenge your initial strategy and forces you to think deeper,- a good level of pressure and the ability to speed up the game.I've played it twice, and will certainly replay it at least another time :)
